Fig. 25.4 Scheme of a Hall-voltage measurement

25.4 Hall-Voltage Measurement

The measurements based on the Hall effect are a powerful investigation tool that exploits the combined action of the electric and magnetic field. The Hall effect is the production of a voltage drop, transverse to the direction of the electric current, due to the application of a magnetic field. The qualitative features of the method are explained with the aid of Fig. 25.4. Consider a uniformly doped, prismatic block of semiconductor. The block is slender, and a constant voltage V is applied to it to produce an electric field E aligned with the longitudinal direction. As a consequence, one can assume that the flow lines of the current density be parallel to E; due to spatial uniformity, such a current density is essentially due to the drift of majority carriers. At the same time, a constant magnetic-induction field B is applied, normal to one of the lateral faces. The upper part of the figure refers to an n-doped semiconductor; there, the majority carriers are electrons, whose average velocity is oriented opposite to the field; it follows that the Lorentz force F = ρ− v− ∧ B (Sect. 4.11) is oriented as shown in the figure. The negative indices in the expression of the Lorentz force remind one that the charge density and average velocity are those of negative charges. The mobile electrons are pushed by the Lorentz force towards the lower face of the device, where they form a negative charge layer. The flow lines of the current density are still parallel to the longitudinal direction; however, their density is not uniform any more. Due to the global charge neutrality, the negative charge layer is compensated by a positive charge layer that forms at the upper face. The two opposite layers, schematically indicated in the diagram in the upper-right part of Fig. 25.4, produce an electric field normal to the upper and lower faces; as a result, a measurable voltage

582 25 Measuring the Semiconductor Parameters

drop (Hall voltage) between the two faces comes into existence: for the example in hand, the voltage of the upper face is larger than that of the lower face.

In a p-doped semiconductor (lower part of the figure), the majority carriers are holes, whose average velocity is oriented in the direction of the field; the Lorentz force F = ρ+ v+∧B is oriented as in the previous case, because both charge density and average velocity change sign with respect to the n-doped semiconductor. The consequence is that the mobile holes are pushed towards the lower face of the device, where they form a positive charge layer. In conclusion, the sign of the Hall voltage is opposite with respect to the case of the n-doped semiconductor.

The analysis of the experiment is based on the drift-diffusion equations incor- porating the magnetic terms, (19.107), (19.123); the diffusion terms are neglected, whence

Jn = qμnnE − qanμ2nnE ∧ B, Jp = qμppE + qapμ2ppE ∧ B. (25.25)

The total current density J = Jn + Jp then reads

J = σE + rσ 2E ∧ B, (25.26)

where σ = q μp p + q μn n is the electric conductivity and

r = q σ 2

(

ap μ 2 p p − an μ2n n

)

= ap μ

2 p p − an μ2n n

q (

μp p + μn n )2 (25.27)

is the Hall coefficient. The two quantities σ and r can be measured independently as shown below; while σ is positive definite, r has a sign. In particular, the following limiting cases hold: for the p-type dopant it is p ≫ n, whence σ ≃ qμpp and r ≃ ap/(qp) > 0; thus,

p = ap q r

, μp = r

ap σ (p ≫ n). (25.28)

Similarly, for the n-type dopant it is n ≫ p, whence σ ≃ q μn n and r ≃ −an/(q n) < 0; thus,

n = − an q r

, μn = − r

an σ (n ≫ p). (25.29)

From (25.28) and (25.29) it follows that the concentration and mobility of the majority carriers can be determined independently, provided σ and r are known. In turn, the measurement of σ and r is easily carried out by applying (25.26) to the prismatic sample of Fig. 25.4. Let iL be the unit vector of the longitudinal direction, and iW the unit vector parallel to B, so that B = B iW . Observing that EW = 0, JW = 0, and E ∧ B = ELBiH − EHBiL, it follows

JL = σEL − rσ 2EHB, JH = σEH + rσ 2ELB, (25.30)

25.5 Measurement of Doping Profiles 583

with JH = 0. In turn, B is small enough to make the following approximations possible:

J = JL ≃ σEL, EH = −rσELB ≃ −rJB. (25.31)

On the other hand it isEL ≃ VL/L, EH ≃ VH /H , and J = I/(W H ), whenceVH = −rBI/W and I/(WH ) = σVL/L. In conclusion,

σ = LI WHVL

, r = −WVH BI

, (25.32)

namely, the two parameters are obtained by combining the Hall voltage with other known physical and geometrical parameters. Typical applications of the mea- surement scheme shown in this section are the measurements of majority-carrier concentrations and mobilities as functions of temperature and dopant concentration.

25.5 Measurement of Doping Profiles

The calculation of the depletion capacitance for an arbitrary doping profile, in the one-dimensional case, has been carried out in Sect. 21.6.3; the analysis has yielded, among others, the two relations (21.72) and (21.73), that are reported below:

dQ = ρ(b) db, C = dQ dψ

= εsc b − a , (25.33)

where C is the differential capacitance per unit area of the space–charge region, whose boundaries are a and b, and ψ = ϕ(b) − ϕ(a). For a strongly-asymmetric junction it is, e.g., b − a ≃ b, and (25.33) become

C ≃ εsc b

, εsc dψ ≃ b ρ(b) db = 1

2 ρ(b) db2 = 1

2 ρ(b) d

( ε2sc

C2

)

. (25.34)

As a consequence,

ρ(b) = 2 εsc

[

d (

1/C2 )

dψ

]−1

. (25.35)

Basing upon (25.35), a measurement scheme can be devised, which proceeds as follows:

1. C is measured at a given bias V , and b is determined from b = εsc/C. 2. C is measured again after slightly varying the bias from V to V +dV = V +dψ . 3. A numerical calculation of the derivative yields ρ(b).

584 25 Measuring the Semiconductor Parameters

An example of application of the above scheme is given with reference to an asym- metric p-n junction with, e.g., a = −lp, b = ln, and ln ≫ lp. In the reverse-bias condition, and using the full-depletion approximation (20.34), it is ρ ≃ q N , whence

N (ln) ≃ 2

qεsc

[

d (

1/C2 )

dψ

]−1

. (25.36)

This provides a method for measuring the dopant distribution.

Appendix A Vector and Matrix Analysis

A.1 Scalar Product

Consider two complex, n-dimensional column vectors

a =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣

a1 ...

an

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦

, b =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣

b1 ...

bn

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦

, (A.1)

whose entries are the components in an n-dimensional Cartesian reference and may depend on position, time, and other parameters. The scalar product of the two vectors is indicated with a · b and is defined as

a · b = n

∑

i=1 a∗i bi . (A.2)

with a∗i the complex conjugate of ai . Two non-vanishing vectors a and b are or- thogonal if a · b = 0. As b · a = (a · b)∗, the order of the factors in the scalar product matters; in fact it becomes irrelevant only when the factors are real. The scalar product is distributive and bilinear; if, say, a = h1 p1 + h2 p2, then

a · (k1 b1 + k2 b2) = h∗1 k1 p1 · b1 + h∗2 k1 p2 · b1 + h∗1 k2 p1 · b2 + h∗2 k2 p2 · b2, (A.3)

where h1,h2, k1, k2 are complex constants (in (A.3), the product k1 b1 is the vector of components k1 b1i , and so on). The modulus of a is defined as

a = |a| = √a · a = (

n ∑

i=1 |ai |2

)1/2

≥ 0. (A.4)

© Springer Science+Business Media New York 2015 585 M. Rudan, Physics of Semiconductor Devices, DOI 10.1007/978-1-4939-1151-6

586 Appendix A Vector and Matrix Analysis

A.2 Schwarz Inequality and Generalizations

Using (A.2, A.3, A.4) one proves the Schwarz inequality

|a · b| ≤ a b. (A.5)

The above is obvious if a = 0 or b = 0; let b �= 0 and define c = a − (a · b) b/b2, whence c · b = 0. It follows

a2 = (

c + a · b b2

b

)

· (

c + a · b b2

b

)

= c2 + |a · b| 2

b2 ≥ |a · b|

2

b2 , (A.6)

which is equivalent to (A.5). The strict equality in (A.5) holds if and only if b = k a, with k any complex constant. Observing that |a · b|2 = ℜ2(a · b) + ℑ2(a · b), from (A.5) one also derives the inequalities −ab ≤ ℜ(a · b) ≤ +ab. Thanks to this, one defines the cosine of the angle ϑ between two non-vanishing vectors a and b as

cosϑ = ℜ(a · b) ab

. (A.7)

Other types of products may be defined besides the scalar product, also involving higher-rank factors: for instance, n× n matrices of the second rank like

A =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣

A11 A12 . . . A1n

A21 A22 . . . A2n ...

... . . .

...

An1 An2 . . . Ann

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦

, B =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣

B11 B12 . . . B1n

B21 B22 . . . B2n ...

... . . .

...

Bn1 Bn2 . . . Bnn

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦

, (A.8)

and so on. Given a second-rank matrix A of entries Aij , its transpose Q = AT is the matrix of entries Qij = Aji . Transposition applies also to vectors: the transpose of the column vector a defined in (A.1) is the row vector aT = [a1, . . . , an]. With these premises, given the column vectors a, b and the matrices A, B, the products A B, A b, and a bT yield, respectively, an n× n matrix, an n-dimensional column vector, and an n× n matrix whose entries are

(A B)ij = n

∑

k=1 Aik Bkj , (A b)i =

n ∑

j=1 Aij bj ,

(

a bT )

ij = ai bj . (A.9)

Applying definitions (A.9) one finds

(A B)T = BT AT , (A b)T = bT AT , (

a bT )T = b aT . (A.10)

A.3 Nabla Operator 587

A.3 Nabla Operator

A further extension of the concepts introduced in this chapter consists in replacing one or more factors with an operator. An important example is that of the real, vector operator nabla,1

∇ =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣

∂/∂x1 ...

∂/∂xn

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦

, (A.11)

where x1, . . . , xn are the coordinates of an n-dimensional Cartesian reference. The product of ∇ and a complex, scalar function f (x1, . . . , xn) is defined in the same manner as the product of a vector and a scalar quantity introduced above: ∇f is a vector of components (∇)if , namely,

∇f =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣

∂f/∂x1 ...

∂f/∂xn

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ . (A.12)

In turn, the scalar product of ∇ and a complex vector a of the same dimension as ∇ yields

∇ · a = ∂a1 ∂x1

+ . . .+ ∂an ∂xn

. (A.13)

The product defined by (A.12) is also called gradient of f , whereas the scalar product (A.13) is also called divergence of a. The corresponding symbols are ∇f = grad f and ∇ · a = div a, respectively. The scalar product of ∇ by itself is called Laplacian operator

∇2 = ∇ · ∇ = ∂ 2

∂x21 + . . .+ ∂

2

∂x2n , (A.14)

then,

∇2f = ∂ 2f

∂x21 + . . .+ ∂

2f

∂x2n , ∇2a =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣

∇2a1 ...

∇2an

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ . (A.15)

Combining the above definitions yields the identities

∇2f = ∇ · (∇f ) = div grad f , ∇ · (f ∗a) = div (f ∗a) = f ∗ div a + grad f · a. (A.16)

1 Symbol ∇ is not a Greek letter. However, the term nabla is a Greek word, meaning “harp”.

588 Appendix A Vector and Matrix Analysis

If, in turn, it is a = grad g, the second relation of (A.16) with the aid of the first one yields the identity

div (f ∗ grad g) = f ∗ ∇2g + grad f · grad g. (A.17)

A.4 Dyadic Products

Sometimes it is convenient to adopt a notation that uses the basis set of real, mutually- orthogonal unit vectors i1, . . . , in associated with the axes of a Cartesian reference. By construction it is ir · is = δrs , where the Kronecker symbol δrs is the entry of indices rs of a second-rank matrix defined as

δrs =

⎧

⎨

⎩

1 s = r 0 s �= r

(A.18)

The expression of vector a in terms of the basis vectors is a = a1 i1 + . . . + an in. The notation applies also to the higher-rank objects; for instance, in this notation the matrix A of (A.8) reads

A = A11 i1 iT1 + A12 i1 iT2 + . . .+ An,n−1 in iTn−1 + Ann in iTn , (A.19) A group like ir iTs is also called dyadic product. Observing that ir is an n-dimensional column vector whose rth entry is equal to 1 while all the other entries are equal to 0, the application of the third equation in (A.9) shows that ir iTs is an n×n matrix whose entry of indices rs is equal to 1, while all the other entries are equal to zero. As a consequence, the form (A.19) expresses A as a sum of matrices, each associated to an individual entry. Using this notation, a product like A b reads

∑

rs Ars ir i T s

∑

k bk ik . On the other hand, due to the second equation in (A.9), the same product is equal to ∑

rs Ars bs ir . This shows that ir i T s ik = ir δsk , that is, the juxtaposition of the right

unit vector of the dyadic product with the next unit vector must be treated as a scalar product.

The relation defined by the second equation in (A.9) applies also when b is replaced with a vector operator, with the provision that the operator is meant to act towards the left. For instance, replacing b with ∇ yields (A∇)i =

∑n j=1 ∂Aij/∂xj . It follows

that the divergence of a second-rank matrix is a column vector of the form

div A = n

∑

j=1

∂A1j

∂xj i1 + . . .+

n ∑

j=1

∂Anj

∂xj in. (A.20)

In turn, considering the product defined by the third equation in (A.9) and replacing b with ∇, still with the provision that the operator acts towards the left, yields (a∇T )ij = ∂ai/∂xj . It follows that the gradient of a column vector is a second-rank matrix of the form

grad a = ∂a1 ∂x1

i1 i T 1 +

∂a1

∂x2 i1 i

T 2 + . . .+

∂an

∂xn−1 i1 i

T n−1 +

∂an

∂xn in i

T n (A.21)

A.6 Vector Product 589

whence, from (A.20),

div (f A) = f div A + A grad f , div (a bT ) = a div b + ( grad a) b. (A.22)

A.5 Divergence Theorem

The divergence theorem (or Gauss theorem) states that ∫

V

div v dV = ∫

S

n · v dS, (A.23)

where V is an n-dimensional volume, dV = dx1 . . . dxn, S the (n− 1)-dimensional surface enclosing V , and n the unit vector normal to the surface element dS, oriented in the outward direction with respect to S. Letting v = f ∗ grad g and using (A.17) yields the first Green theorem

∫

S

f ∗ ∂g

∂n dS =

∫

V

(

f ∗ ∇2g + grad f · grad g )

dV , (A.24)

where ∂g/∂n = n · grad g is the derivative of g in the direction of n. It is easily found that (A.24) is the generalization to n dimensions of the integration by parts. Rewriting (A.24) after letting v = g grad f ∗, and subtracting from (A.24), yields the second Green theorem

∫

S

(

f ∗ ∂g

∂n − g ∂f

∗

∂n

)

dS = ∫

V

(

f ∗ ∇2g − g∇2f ∗ )

dV. (A.25)

A special case of the first Green theorem occurs when vector b = grad g is constant; the relation (A.24) then reduces to

∫

S

f ∗ n dS · b = ∫

V

grad f dV · b, b = const. (A.26)

As identity (A.26) holds for any choice of b, the two integrals in it are equal to each other.

A.6 Vector Product

Another possible product between two vectors is the vector product a ∧ b, which yields a column vector. In contrast with the other products introduced in this section, the definition of the vector product will be limited to the three-dimensional case; it is given as the expansion of a determinant, namely,

a ∧ b =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎣

i1 i2 i3

a1 a2 a3

b1 b2 b3

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎦

⇒ a ∧ b =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎣

a2b3 − a3b2 a3b1 − a1b3 a1b2 − a2b1

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎦ . (A.27)

590 Appendix A Vector and Matrix Analysis

From (A.27) it follows b ∧ a = −a ∧ b and a ∧ a = 0. The latter also shows that, if two non-vanishing vectors are parallel to each other, say, b = k a �= 0, then a ∧ b = 0. When the vector product involves the unit vectors associated to the axes of a right-handed Cartesian reference, the following relations are found:

i1 ∧ i2 = i3, i2 ∧ i3 = i1, i3 ∧ i1 = i2. (A.28)

An intrinsic relation that provides the modulus of a ∧ b is found by specifying (A.7) for the case of three-dimensional, real vectors, this yielding

cos2 ϑ = 1 − sin2 ϑ =

( ∑3

i=1 ai bi )2

a2 b2 . (A.29)

As cosϑ = 1 when the two vectors are parallel, b = k a, k > 0, while cosϑ = −1 when they are antiparallel, b = k a, k < 0, the range of ϑ is [0,π ]. Letting rij = ai bj−aj bi and observing that (

∑3 i=1 a

2 i ) (

∑3 i=1 b

2 i ) = (

∑3 i=1 ai bi)

2+r223+r231+r212 provides

sin2 ϑ = r 2 23 + r231 + r212

a2 b2 = |a ∧ b|

2

a2 b2 , |a ∧ b| = a b sin ϑ , (A.30)

where sin ϑ ≥ 0 due to the range of ϑ .

A.7 Mixed Product

The vector product a ∧ b can in turn be scalarly multiplied by another vector c, to yield a scalar quantity called mixed product. For the sake of simplicity, in the definition of the mixed product the three vectors will be considered real. From (A.2) one finds

a ∧ b · c = 3

∑

i=1 (a ∧ b)i ci =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎣

c1 c2 c3

a1 a2 a3

b1 b2 b3

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎦

=

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎣

a1 a2 a3

b1 b2 b3

c1 c2 c3

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎦ . (A.31)

The two determinants in (A.31) are equal because they transform into each other by interchanging rows an even number of times. On the other hand, from their equality it follows a∧b·c = a ·b∧c, namely, the mixed product is invariant upon interchange of the “wedge” and “dot” symbols.

Considering three non-vanishing vectors a, b, c, where a and b are not parallel to each other, and remembering the properties of determinants, one finds that the mixed product vanishes if c is parallel to a or parallel to b. In fact,

a ∧ b · a = a ∧ b · b = 0. (A.32)

A.8 Rotational of a Vector 591

It follows that the vector product a ∧ b is normal to both a and b, namely, is normal to the plane defined by the two non-parallel vectors a and b. If one associates the plane of a and b with that of the unit vectors i1 and i2 then, using (A.28), the vector product simplifies to a ∧ b = (a1 b2 − a2 a1) i3, that provides the information about the direction of a ∧ b. Finally, using (A.27) twice provides the expression for the double vector product

a ∧ (b ∧ c) = a · c b − a · b c, (a ∧ b) ∧ c = a · c b − b · c a. (A.33)

A.8 Rotational of a Vector

The expressions involving the vector product can be extended to the case where one or two vectors are replaced with the nabla operator (A.11). The vector product

∇ ∧ a =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎣

i1 i2 i3

∂/∂x1 ∂/∂x2 ∂/∂x3

a1 a2 a3

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎦

=

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎣

∂a3/∂x2 − ∂a2/∂x3 ∂a1/∂x3 − ∂a3/∂x1 ∂a2/∂x1 − ∂a1/∂x2

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎦

(A.34)

is also called rotational of a, the corresponding symbol being ∇ ∧ a = rot a. Com- bining (A.34) with the three-dimensional case of (A.12) and (A.13) shows that the following identities hold:

rot (f a) = f rot a + grad f ∧ a, rot grad f = 0, div rot a = 0, (A.35) rot rot a = grad div a − ∇2a, div (a ∧ b) = b · rot a − a · rot b. (A.36)

Integrating the second equation in (A.36) over a three-dimensional volume V and using (A.23) yields the identity

∫

S

n · a ∧ b dS = ∫

V

(b · rot a − a · rot b) dV. (A.37)

A special case of (A.37) occurs when vector a is constant. In fact, noting that n·a∧b = −n · b ∧ a = −n ∧ b · a, (A.37) reduces to

a · ∫

S

n ∧ b dS = a · ∫

V

rot b dV , a = const. (A.38)

As identity (A.38) holds for any choice of a, the two integrals in it are equal to each other.

592 Appendix A Vector and Matrix Analysis

Fig. A.1 Rotational theorem (Sect. A.9): orientation of the unit vectors

n

−n

b

t

A.9 Rotational Theorem

The rotational theorem (or Stokes theorem) states that ∫

S

n · rot v dS = ∫

C

t · v dC, (A.39)

where C is the boundary curve of the open surface S, t the unit vector tangent to C, and n the unit vector normal to the surface element dS. The direction of the unit vectors is such that the orientation of b = t ∧ n is external with respect to the curve (Fig. A.1).

A.10 Helmholtz Theorem

A vector u such that rot u = 0 is called irrotational. From the second identity in (A.35) one finds that, if u = grad f , then u is irrotational. The inverse is not true in general; however, if the domain of u is simply connected, the condition rot u = 0 implies that u can be expressed as a gradient: u = grad f .

A vector v such that div v = 0 is called solenoidal. From the third identity in (A.35) one finds that, if v = rot a, then v is solenoidal. The inverse is not true in general; however, if the domain of v is simply connected, the condition div v = 0 implies that v can be expressed as a rotational: v = rot a.

The Helmholtz theorem states that a vector w defined in a simply-connected domain can be expressed in a unique manner as the sum of an irrotational and a solenoidal vector:

w = grad f + rot a. (A.40) Scalar f is found by taking the divergence of both sides of (A.40) and using the identities div grad f = ∇2f , div rot a = 0. In turn, vector a is found by taking the rotational of both sides of (A.40) and using the first identity in (A.36) along with the auxiliary condition div a = 0. By this procedure it is found that f and a fulfill the relations

∇2f = div w, ∇2a = − rot w. (A.41)

A.12 Wronskian Determinant 593

The right hand sides of (A.41) are known because w is prescribed. As a consequence, the problem of finding f and a is equivalent to solving a set of Poisson equations. The solution of (A.41) is unique provided that w vanishes at infinity faster than r−1 [65, Sect. XI.3]. Unless some additional prescriptions are imposed on f and a, (A.40) still holds if one adds to f an arbitrary constant and, to a, the gradient of an arbitrary scalar function.

A.11 Doubly-Stochastic Matrices

Consider a set of M square matrices of order M , S1, . . . , SM , and a set of M real, non-negative numbers θk such that θ1 + . . .+ θM = 1. The matrix

S = M ∑

k=1 θkSk (A.42)

is called convex combination of the Sk matrices. The following theorem is easily proved: if the matrices Sk are doubly stochastic,2

then S is doubly stochastic as well. In fact from the definition of S it is (S)ij = ∑M

k=1 θk(Sk)ij whence, adding the terms row-wise,

M ∑

j=1 (S)ij =

M ∑

k=1 θk

M ∑

j=1 (Sk)ij =

M ∑

k=1 θk = 1. (A.43)

The same result is obtained when summing column-wise. As permutation matri- ces are doubly stochastic, from the above theorem the special case follows: a convex combination of permutation matrices is a doubly-stochastic matrix. The inverse prop- erty also holds: a doubly-stochastic matrix is a convex combination of permutation matrices [5].

A.12 Wronskian Determinant

The Wronskian determinant provides the condition of linear independence of func- tions [51, Sect. 5.2]. Although its properties hold for any number of functions, they will be discussed here for the case of two functions only, say, u and v defined on some interval of the independent variable x. It is convenient to seek for the condition of linear dependence first. If u, v are linearly dependent, then two non-vanishing constants c1, c2 exist such that

c1 u + c2 v = 0 (A.44)

2 The definition of doubly-stochastic matrix is given in Sect. 7.6.1.

594 Appendix A Vector and Matrix Analysis

for all x in the interval. If (A.44) holds, it is easily found that both c1 and c2 must differ from zero. Also, as the function at the left hand side of (A.44) vanishes identically, its derivative vanishes as well. Such a derivative exists because u and v are supposed to be solutions of a second-order differential equation. Then,

c1 u ′ + c2 v′ = 0 (A.45)

for all x in the interval. As (A.44, A.45) hold together, for all x the two constants c1, c2 are the non-trivial solution of a homogeneous algebraic system. Now, if the non- trivial solution of the algebraic system exists for all x, the determinantW = u v′−u′ v must vanish identically. That is, the condition W = 0 (identically) is necessary for the linear dependence of u, v. As a consequence, the condition W �= 0 (identically) is sufficient for the linear independence of u, v.

Appendix B Coordinates

B.1 Spherical Coordinates

When the problem in hand has a spherical symmetry it is convenient to describe the position of a particle by means of the spherical coordinates.

With reference to Fig. B.1, the transformation relations between the Cartesian (x, y, z) and spherical (r ,ϑ ,ϕ) coordinates are

⎧

⎪ ⎪ ⎨

⎪ ⎪ ⎩

x = r sin ϑ cosϕ y = r sin ϑ sin ϕ z = r cosϑ

⎧

⎪ ⎪ ⎨

⎪ ⎪ ⎩

r2 = x2 + y2 + z2

cosϑ = z/r tan ϕ = y/x

(B.1)

that are a special case of (1.26). The limits of the spherical coordinates are 0 ≤ r < ∞, 0 ≤ ϑ ≤ π , 0 ≤ ϕ < 2π . The 3 × 3 matrix of the partial derivatives of the Cartesian coordinates with respect to the spherical ones, expressed in terms of the latter (Jacobian matrix), is

∂(x, y, z)

∂(r ,ϑ ,ϕ) =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎣

sin ϑ cosϕ r cosϑ cosϕ −r sin ϑ sin ϕ sin ϑ sin ϕ r cosϑ sin ϕ r sin ϑ cosϕ

cosϑ −r sin ϑ 0

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎦

, (B.2)

where the left hand side is a short-hand notation for a matrix whose elements are J11 = ∂x/∂r , J12 = ∂x/∂ϑ , and so on. The Jacobian determinant is

J = det ∂(x, y, z) ∂(r ,ϑ ,ϕ)

= r2 sin ϑ. (B.3)

The matrix of the partial derivatives of the spherical coordinates with respect to the Cartesian ones, expressed in terms of the former, is

∂(r ,ϑ ,ϕ)

∂(x, y, z) =

⎡

⎢ ⎢ ⎣

sin ϑ cosϕ sin ϑ sin ϕ cosϑ

(1/r) cosϑ cosϕ (1/r) cosϑ sin ϕ −(1/r) sin ϑ −(1/r) sin ϕ/ sin ϑ (1/r) cosϕ/ sin ϑ 0

⎤

⎥ ⎥ ⎦

,

(B.4) © Springer Science+Business Media New York 2015 595 M. Rudan, Physics of Semiconductor Devices, DOI 10.1007/978-1-4939-1151-6

whence

det ∂(r ,ϑ ,ϕ)

J . (B.5)

To calculate (B.4) consider, e.g., the last term of the second row, (∂ϑ/∂z)xy = −(1/r) sin ϑ . The second line of the second group of (B.1) yields (∂ cosϑ/∂z)xy = 1/r − z2/r3, where (∂r/∂z)xy = z/r has been used, that in turn derives from the first line of the second group of (B.1). The relation z = r cosϑ then yields (∂ cosϑ/∂z)xy = (1/r) sin2 ϑ . On the other hand the same quantity can also be writ- ten as (∂ cosϑ/∂z)xy = − sin ϑ (∂ϑ/∂z)xy . Comparing the two expressions above yields the result sought.

Differentiating with respect to time the first of (B.1) yields the relations

⎧

⎪ ⎪ ⎨

⎪ ⎪ ⎩

ẋ = ṙ sin ϑ cosϕ + r ϑ̇ cosϑ cosϕ − r ϕ̇ sin ϑ sin ϕ ẏ = ṙ sin ϑ sin ϕ + r ϑ̇ cosϑ sin ϕ + r ϕ̇ sin ϑ cosϕ ż = ṙ cosϑ − r ϑ̇ sin ϑ

(B.6)

that express the components of the velocity in the Cartesian reference as functions of the generalized coordinates r ,ϑ ,ϕ and generalized velocities ṙ , ϑ̇ , ϕ̇ of the spherical reference. From (B.6) the expression of the kinetic energy in spherical coordinates follows:

T = 1 2 m (ẋ2 + ẏ2 + ż2) = 1

2 m

(

ṙ2 + r2ϑ̇2 + r2ϕ̇2 sin2 ϑ )

. (B.7)

B.2 Polar Coordinates

To describe the motion of particles confined over a plane one may adopt, instead of the Cartesian coordinates x, y, the polar coordinates r ,ϕ. The relations between the two groups of coordinates are

B.3 Coordinate Rotation 597

⎧

⎨

⎩

x = r cosϕ y = r sin ϕ

⎧

⎨

⎩

r2 = x2 + y2

tan ϕ = y/x (B.8)

The limits of the polar coordinates are 0 ≤ r < ∞, 0 ≤ ϕ < 2π . The Jacobian matrix and the Jacobian determinant are, respectively,

∂(x, y)

∂(r ,ϕ) =

⎡

⎣ cosϕ −r sin ϕ sin ϕ r cosϕ

⎤

⎦ , J = det ∂(x, y) ∂(r ,ϕ)

= r. (B.9)

Differentiating with respect to time the first of (B.8) yields the relations ⎧

⎨

⎩

ẋ = ṙ cosϕ − r ϕ̇ sin ϕ ẏ = ṙ sin ϕ + r ϕ̇ cosϕ

(B.10)

that express the components of the velocity in the Cartesian reference as functions of the generalized coordinates r ,ϕ and generalized velocities ṙ , ϕ̇ of the polar reference. From (B.10) the expression of the kinetic energy in polar coordinates follows:

T = 1 2 m (ẋ2 + ẏ2) = 1

2 m

(

ṙ2 + r2ϕ̇2 )

. (B.11)

B.3 Coordinate Rotation

Consider a coordinate transformation that consists in a rotation around the origin, bringing a right-handed system of coordinates x = (x1, x2, x3) into another right- handed system s = (s1, s2, s3). The transformation is described by the linear relations

⎧

⎪ ⎪ ⎨

⎪ ⎪ ⎩

s1 = a11 x1 + a12 x2 + a13 x3 s2 = a21 x1 + a22 x2 + a23 x3 s3 = a31 x1 + a32 x2 + a33 x3

(B.12)

which can be recast in the matrix form s = Ax. It is known that a matrix describing this type of transformation is orthogonal [42, Sect. 4.2], namely,

3 ∑

i=1 aij aik = δjk , detA = 1, A−1 = AT , j , k = 1, 2, 3, (B.13)

where apex T indicates the transpose. From (B.13) it follows (

A−1 )T = A. As a

consequence, the effect of the rotation onto the modulus of a particle’s velocity is found from

(

ẋT , ẋ )

= [ (

A−1 ṡ )T

, A−1 ṡ ]

= (

ṡT A, A−1 ṡ )

= (

ṡT , A A−1 ṡ )

= (

ṡT , ṡ )

.

(B.14)

598 Appendix B Coordinates

In (B.14) the symbol (aT , b) denotes the scalar product between the vectors a and b, namely, it is equivalent to a · b. The above calculation shows that u2 = (ẋT , ẋ) is invariant under rotation of the coordinate system. The same reasoning applies to the modulus of position r2 = (xT , x) = (sT , s).

B.4 Differential Operators Under Coordinate Transformations

Consider the coordinate transformation between the two sets xi , ξi , i = 1, 2, . . . , n:

ξi = ξi(x1, . . . , xn), xi = xi(ξ1, . . . , ξn). (B.15)

If a function f is transformed using the above, the following hold:

∂f

∂xi =

n ∑

B.5 Density of States

Consider a function s that depends on the coordinates u, v, w, and on one or more additional parameters that will collectively be indicated with σ . Let

S(σ ) = ∫∫∫

s(u, v, w, σ ) du dv dw, (B.26)

where the integration is carried out over the whole domain of u, v, w. Next, consider the transformation from the original variables to the new variables α, β, η,

α = α(u, v, w), β = β(u, v, w), η = η(u, v, w), J = ∂(u, v, w) ∂(α,β, η)

, (B.27)

which is assumed to be invertible, so that the Jacobian determinant J does not vanish. After the transformation is carried out, (B.26) takes the form

S(σ ) = ∫∫∫

s(α,β, η, σ ) |J | dα dβ dη. (B.28)

It may happen that one is interested in the dependence of s on one of the new variables, say, η, rather than in the details about its dependence on the whole set of new variables. In this case one first carries out the integrals with respect to α and β in (B.28), to find

h(η, σ ) = ∫∫

s(α,β, η, σ ) |J | dα dβ. (B.29)

Then one defines

b(η) = ∫∫

|J | dα dβ. (B.30)

600 Appendix B Coordinates

A function like b(η) plays an important role in many physical problems (e.g., Sects. 14.6, 15.8.1, 15.8.2). For this reason, although its derivation in this section is of a purely formal nature, b(η) will be called density of states in η. Note that the density of states depends only on the structure of the variable transformation (B.27) and (at most) on η. The form of (B.29) and (B.30) shows that the ratio s̄ = h/b is a weighed average of s(α,β, η, σ ) over the two variables α and β, that uses |J | as weight. Introducing the definition of s̄ into (B.28) gives the latter the form

S(σ ) = ∫

b(η) s̄(η, σ ) dη. (B.31)

If s happens to be independent of α and β, definition (B.29) yields h = s b, whence s̄(η, σ ) = s(η, σ ). The derivation of b is not limited to a three-dimensional case; in fact it applies to any number of dimensions. In the following, a few examples in one, two, and three dimensions are given, in which one of the transformation relations (B.27), namely, η = η(u, v, w), has a quadratic form; these examples are in fact particularly significant for the physical applications, where η stands for the energy and u, v, w stand for the generalized coordinates.

Considering a one-dimensional case with η = u2, one finds3

u = ±η1/2, |J | = ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣

∂u

∂η

∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ = 1

2 η−1/2, b(η) = 2 1

2 η−1/2 = η−1/2. (B.32)

This case is straightforward because there are no other variables involved in the transformation. Instead, in the two-dimensional case with η = u2 + v2, a convenient transformation involving the second variable is of the polar type (B.8), specifically, u = η1/2 cosϕ, v = η1/2 sin ϕ. One finds

|J | = 1 2

, b(η) = ∫ 2π

0

1

2 dϕ = π. (B.33)

In the three-dimensional case with η = u2 + v2 + w2, a convenient transformation involving the other two variables is of the spherical type (B.1), specifically, u = η1/2 sin ϑ cosϕ, v = η1/2 sin ϑ sin ϕ, w = η1/2 cosϑ . One finds

|J | = 1 2 η1/2 sin ϑ , b(η) =

∫ 2π

0

∫ π

0

1

2 η1/2 sin ϑ dϑ dϕ = 2π η1/2. (B.34)

The above examples show that, despite the fact that the η = η(u, v, w) relation is quadratic in all cases, the form of b(η) changes depending on the number of spatial dimensions.

Still considering the case where one of the transformation relations (B.27) has a quadratic form, the analysis can be extended to arbitrary values of the number

3 Factor 2 in the last expression of (B.32) accounts for the fact that both positive and negative parts of the segment [− η1/2,+η1/2] must be considered.

B.5 Density of States 601

of spatial dimensions. As a starting point, and considering provisionally the three- dimensional case, one notes from (B.30) that the following equality holds:4

B = ∫

b(η) dη = ∫∫∫

|J | dα dβ dη = ∫∫∫

du dv dw. (B.35)

Remembering the definition of b, it follows that B is the number of states in the domain of u, v, w. Due to the last integral in (B.34), B is also equal to the volume of such a domain; in turn, due to the first integral, B can be thought of as the sum of the volumes of elementary shells of thickness dη, with b(η) the area of each shell (that is, the area of the two-dimensional surface η = const). These observations provide the key to extending the analysis to the case where η is a quadratic form in an arbitrary number of dimensions,

u21 + u22 + . . .+ u2n = η, η = g2. (B.36)

Letting η = const, (B.36) is the equation of an (n− 1)-dimensional sphere of radius g ≥ 0 immersed into the n-dimensional space. The problem is thus reduced to expressing the area of the sphere in terms of η; although it can be solved by using a generalization of the spherical coordinates to n dimensions, a more elegant approach consists in finding a recursive expression involving also the sphere’s volume.

To this purpose, let Vn indicate the volume of a sphere of an n-dimensional space, and let Sn−1 indicate the surface area of the same sphere. When n = 1, the sphere is a segment whose volume is the length V1 = 2g; for n = 2, the sphere is a circle whose volume is the area V2 = π g2; for n = 3 it is V3 = (4/3)π g3; for n = 4 it is V4 = π2 g4/2, and so on; in turn, for n = 2 the surface is a circumference whose area is the length S1 = 2π g; for n = 3 it is S2 = 4π g2; for n = 4 it is S3 = 2π2 g3, and so on. Consistently with the expression of B as the integral of b given by (B.35), one finds from the above values the general relation

Vn = g

n Sn−1. (B.37)

Combining (B.37) with V1 = 2g also yields S0 = 2, that is, the “surface” of the segment considered above; such a surface is made of the segment’s endpoints {−1,+1}. From (B.37) it also follows that Vn ∝ gn and Sn−1 ∝ gn−1, whence Sn ∝ g Vn−1 and V0 = const. From the values found above one finds S2/(g V1) = S3/(g V2) = 2π ; it follows that Sn = 2π g Vn−1 and V0 = 1. The latter is the “volume” of a sphere in a zero-dimensional space. The recursive relation involving the volumes then reads

Vn = g

n Sn−1 =

g

n 2π g Vn−2 =

2π g2

n Vn−2, V0 = 1, V1 = 2g. (B.38)

4 In the practical applications of the concepts illustrated here, the integrands in (B.35) embed a constant factor Q0, called density of states in the u, v, w space which, besides describing some properties of the physical problem under investigation, makes B dimensionless. Here, all variables involved are dimensionless, and Q0 is set equal to unity.

602 Appendix B Coordinates

The above can further by improved by observing that the sequenceV0, V1, . . . embeds Euler’s Gamma function of half-integer order; in fact, combining (B.37) and (B.38) with the definitions of Sect. C.10, yields

Vn = πn/2

Γ (n/2 + 1) g n, Sn−1 =

nπn/2

Γ (n/2 + 1) g n−1. (B.39)

The last step consists in expressing the result in terms of η. This is accomplished by noting that b(η) dη = Sn−1(g) dg, where g = √η and dg = d√η = dη/(2√η); then, one finds

b(η) dη = nπ n/2η(n−1)/2

Γ (n/2 + 1) dη

2η1/2 , b(η) = nπ

n/2

2Γ (n/2 + 1) η n/2−1. (B.40)

Letting n = 1, 2, 3 in the second expression of (B.40) renders (B.32), (B.33), (B.34), respectively.

Appendix C Special Integrals

C.1 Sine Integral

Define the two functions

si(t) = −π 2 +

∫ t

0

sin x

x dx, N (a) =

∫ ∞

0

sin (ax)

x dx. (C.1)

The first of them is called sine integral and fulfills the limit limt→∞ si = 0, whence N (1) = π/2. To demonstrate the above one starts from the functions

F (y) = ∫ ∞

0 exp (−x) sin (xy)

x dx, G(y) =

∫ ∞

0 exp (−xy) sin x

x dx, y ≥ 0.

(C.2)

The following hold true: F (0) = 0, G(0) = N (1), F (1) = G(1), and

dF

dy =

∫ ∞

0 exp (−x) cos (xy) dx, dG

dy =

∫ ∞

0 exp (−xy) sin x dx. (C.3)

Integrating (C.3) by parts twice yields dF/dy = 1/(1+ y2), dG/dy = −1/(1+ y2) whence

F (y) = arctan y + F (0), G(y) = − arctan y +G(0), 0 ≤ y < π 2 . (C.4)

It followsF (1) = F (0)+π/4 = π/4 andF (1) = G(1) = G(0)−π/4 = N (1)−π/4. Combining the above yields the result sought. This implicitly proves the convergence of the integrals in (C.1). The calculation of the second of (C.1) is now straightforward and yields

N (a) =

⎧

⎪ ⎪ ⎨

⎪ ⎪ ⎩

−π/2, a < 0, 0, a = 0,

+π/2, a > 0. (C.5)

0 |a| > 2 (C.13)

This result shows that the derivative with respect to a of the integral sought is piecewise constant in the interval −2 < a < +2, and vanishes elsewhere. The integral is also continuous with respect to a and does not diverge, because | sin2 x/x2| ≤ | sin x/x| and (C.9) converges. C.2 Fourier Transform

Let f (x) be a function defined over the entire x axis. Its Fourier transform is defined as the integral

G(k) = Fxf = 1√ 2π

∫ +∞

−∞ f (x) exp ( − i k x) dx. (C.16)

In turn, the Fourier antitransform is defined as

f (x) = F−1x G = 1√ 2π

∫ +∞

−∞ G(k) exp (i k x) dk. (C.17)

Combining (C.16) and (C.17) provides a representation of f in the form

f (x) = 1 2π

∫ +∞

−∞ exp (i k x)

[∫ +∞

−∞ f (ξ ) exp ( − i k ξ ) dξ

]

dk. (C.18)

A sufficient condition for the representation (C.18) is ∫ +∞

−∞ |f (x)| dx < ∞. (C.19)

606 Appendix C Special Integrals

If f is discontinuous of the first kind at some point x0, the left hand side of (C.18) must be replaced with [f (x+0 ) + f (x−0 )]/2. As the condition (C.19) is sufficient, but not necessary, there are functions that admit an integral representation like (C.18) without fulfilling (C.19). An important example is the unit step function shown in Sect. C.1.

If f depends also on one or more parameters, f = f (x, u, v, . . . ), then it is G = G(k, u, v, . . . ). In an n-dimensional space, defining the vectors x = (x1, . . . , xn) and k = (k1, . . . , kn), the Fourier transform reads

G(k) = Fxf = 1

(2π )n/2

∫ +∞

−∞ . . .

∫ +∞

−∞ f (x) exp ( − i k · x) dx1 . . . dxn. (C.20)

A useful relation is found by differentiating both sides of (C.17). To this purpose, one must assume that the conditions for exchanging the derivative with the integral are fulfilled. It is found

df

dx = 1√

2π

∫ +∞

−∞ i k G(k) exp (ikx) dk. (C.21)

Iterating the procedure yields

dnf

dxn = 1√

2π

∫ +∞

−∞ (i k)n G(k) exp (ikx) dk, (C.22)

showing that, if G(k) is the Fourier transform of f (x), then the Fourier transform of dnf/dxx is (i k)n G(k). Relations like (C.21) and (C.22) are useful, for instance, in the solution of linear differential equations with constant coefficients, because they turn differential relations into polynomial relations (compare with the solution of the diffusion equation carried out in Sect. 23.4).

C.3 Gauss Integral

The relation

IG = ∫ +∞

0 exp (−x2) dx =

∫ 0

−∞ exp (−x2) dx. (C.23)

is called Gauss integral or Poisson integral. To calculate its value one may start from the double integral

F (R) = ∫ ∫

Σ(R) exp [−(x2 + y2)] dxdy, (C.24)

whereΣ(R) is a circle of radiusR centered on the origin. Using the polar coordinates (B.8) yields

F (R) = ∫ 2π

0 dϑ

∫ R

0 exp ( − ρ2) ρ dρ = π [1 − exp ( − R2)], (C.25)

C.3 Gauss Integral 607

whence limR→∞ F (R) = π . On the other hand, due to (C.24) it is also

lim R→∞

F (R) = ∫∫ +∞

−∞ exp [−(x2 + y2)] dxdy = lim

)2

.

(C.26)

Combining (C.25, C.26) with (C.23) provides ∫ +∞

2 . (C.27)

From (C.27) it follows that for any λ > 0 it is

I0(λ) = ∫ ∞

2

λ . (C.28)

Another integral generated by exp ( − λx2) is

I1(λ) = ∫ ∞

2λ . (C.29)

Thanks to (C.28) and (C.29) it is possible to calculate all integrals of the form

In(λ) = ∫ ∞

0 xn exp ( − λx2) dx, n ≥ 0. (C.30)

d

(C.31)

in combination with (C.29) yields all the integrals whose index is odd,

I2m+1 = m! 2

I2m(λ) = (2m− 1)!!

∫ +∞

(C.35)

The results of this section still hold for a complex λ with ℜλ > 0.

C.4 Dirac’s δ

Consider a function ΔB(x, a) defined as follows:

ΔB =

⎧

⎨

⎩

1/a −a/2 ≤ x ≤ +a/2 0 x < −a/2, x > a/2

(C.36)

with a > 0. The above definition yields

lim a→0

ΔB =

⎧

⎨

⎩

0 x �= 0 +∞ x = 0

, ∫ +∞

−∞ ΔB(x, a) dx =

1

a

∫ +a/2

−a/2 dx = 1.

(C.37)

As the value of the integral in (C.37) is independent of a, the integral is equal to unity also in the limit a → 0. Figure C.1 shows how the form of ΔB changes with a: the width of the peak decreases as a decreases, while its height increases so that the area subtending the function remains constant. Note that the procedure depicted above gives a different result if one carries out the integration after calculating the limit. In other terms, the integration and the limit are to be carried out in a specific order (integration first). For a continuous function f (x) the mean-value theorem provides

∫ +∞

−∞ ΔB(x, a) f (x) dx =

1

a

∫ +a/2

−a/2 f (x) dx = f (x̄), (C.38)

with −a/2 < x̄ < +a/2. As a consequence,

lim a→0

∫ +∞

−∞ ΔB(x, a) f (x) dx = f (0). (C.39)

C.4 Dirac’s δ 609

This result is expressed in a more compact form by defining a linear functional δ(x) (called Dirac’s symbol) such that

∫ +∞

−∞ δ(x) f (x) dx = f (0). (C.40)

The functional associates the number f (0) to the function f (x). If the reasoning leading to (C.40) is repeated after shifting ΔB from the origin to another point x0, one finds the generalization of (C.40)

∫ +∞

−∞ δ(x − x0) f (x) dx = f (x0). (C.41)

From (C.41) and (C.16) one obtains

∫ +∞

−∞ δ(x − x0) dx = 1, Fxδ(x − x0) =

1√ 2π

exp ( − i k x0). (C.42)

The antitransform (C.17) then reads

δ(x − x0) = 1

2π

∫ +∞

−∞ exp [i k (x − x0)] dk, (C.43)

that provides an integral representation of the Dirac δ. However, it is important to note that (C.43) has no meaning unless it is used within an integral like, e.g., (C.41). With this provision, one can consider the Dirac δ as the “derivative” of the step function; in fact, after a suitable change in the symbols, one finds that the integral at the right hand side of (C.43) is the derivative with respect to x of the integral at the right hand side of (C.8). More details about the integral representation of the Dirac δ are given in Sect. C.5.

The function ΔB(x, a) defined above is an example of generating function of the Dirac δ. Several other examples may be given, as shown below. In all cases, if the generating function Δ(x, x0, a) is centered at some point x0, it is even with respect to x0 and has the properties lima→0 Δ = 0 if x �= x0 and lima→0 Δ = +∞ if x = x0. Consider for instance the Lorentzian function (centered at x0 = 0)

ΔL = a/π

a2 + x2 , ∫ +∞

−∞ ΔL dx =

1

π

∫ +∞

−∞

d

dx arctan

(x

a

)

dx = 1, (C.44)

with a > 0. Apart from the limiting case a → 0 the function has only one maximum that occurs at x = 0 and equals 1/(aπ ). For x = ±a the function’s value halves with respect to the maximum, so 2a is conventionally taken as the width of ΔL. The product 2/π of the maximum value by the conventional width is independent of a and is of order unity. Finally, for a continuous function f (x) it is

lim a→0

∫ +∞

−∞ ΔL(x, a)f (x) dx = f (0). (C.45)

610 Appendix C Special Integrals

Another example of a δ-generating function is the parameterized Gaussian function (centered at x0 = 0)

ΔG = exp (−x2/a2)

a √ π

, a > 0, ∫ +∞

−∞ ΔG(x, a) dx = 1 (C.46)

(more details about this function and integrals related to it are given in Sects. C.3 and C.8). The function has only one maximum that occurs at x = 0 and equals 1/(a√π ). For x = ±a√log 2 ≃ ±0.833 a the function’s value halves with respect to the maximum, this yielding a conventional width of 2a

√ log 2. The product 2

√ log 2/

√ π

of the maximum value by the conventional width is independent of a and of order unity. For a continuous function f (x) it is

lim a→0

∫ +∞

−∞ ΔG(x, a)f (x) dx = f (0). (C.47)

A final example of a δ-generating function is the negative derivative of the Fermi- Dirac statistics (centered at x0 = 0)

ΔF = − d

dx

1

exp (x/a) + 1 ]2 , a > 0, (C.48)

∫ +∞

∫ −∞

+∞

d

1

exp (x/a) + 1 dx = 1. (C.49)

(more details about this function and integrals related to it are given in Sect. C.13). The function has only one maximum that occurs at x = 0 and equals 1/(4a). For x = ±a log (3+

√ 8) ≃ ±1.76 a the function’s value halves with respect to the maximum,

this yielding a conventional width of 2a log (3+ √

8). The product (1/2) log (3+ √

8) of the maximum value by the conventional width is independent of a and of order unity. For a continuous function f (x) it is

lim a→0

∫ +∞

−∞ ΔF (x, a)f (x) dx = f (0). (C.50)

The δ-generating functions Δ vanish for x → ±∞, otherwise they would not be integrable from −∞ to +∞. Assuming that Δ is differentiable with respect to x yields, after integrating by parts,

∫ +∞

−∞ f (x)

dΔ(x, a)

dx dx = [Δ(x, a) f (x)]+∞−∞ −

∫ +∞

−∞ Δ(x, a)

df

dx dx, (C.51)

with f a differentiable function. In (C.51) the integrated part is zero because Δ vanishes at infinity. Taking the limit a → 0 at both sides of (C.51) and using (C.40) yields

∫ +∞

−∞ f (x)

dδ(x)

dx dx = −

∫ +∞

−∞ δ(x)

df

dx dx = −f ′(0), (C.52)

which is used as the definition of the derivative of δ. Such a definition generalizes to

∫ +∞

C.5 Some Properties of Dirac’s δ

An integral representation of δ is derived from (C.18) after rearranging it as

f (x) = ∫ +∞

−∞

[∫ +∞

−∞

exp [i k (x − ξ )] 2π

dk

]

f (ξ ) dξ (C.54)

and comparing with (C.41):

δ(ξ − x) = ∫ +∞

−∞

exp [i k (x − ξ )] 2π

dk. (C.55)

Replacing k with −k in (C.55) shows that δ is even with respect to its argument, δ(x − ξ ) = δ(ξ − x). Also, comparing (C.55) with (C.16) shows that δ(ξ − x) is the Fourier transform of exp (i k x)/

√ 2π . The generalization of (C.55) to more than

one dimension is immediate; e.g., the three-dimensional case reads

δ(g − x) = ∫∫∫ +∞

−∞

exp [i k · (x − g)] (2π )3

d3k. (C.56)

The discrete-case analogue of (C.56) is given by (C.117, C.121), where the gen- eralization of the Kronecker symbol is given. Note that the latter is dimensionless, whereas the units of Dirac’s δ depend on its argument: by way of example, the inte- gral

∫ +∞ −∞ δ(ξ − x) dξ = 1 shows that the units of δ(ξ − x) are the inverse of those of

612 Appendix C Special Integrals

Fig. C.3 Generation of a Dirac δ using a parameterized Gaussian function. The width of the peak is proportional to a

-4 -2 0 2 4 x

0.0

0.5

1.0

1.5

Δ G

( x

, a

)

dξ ; similarly, the integral ∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ δ(g − x) d3g = 1 shows that the units of δ(g − x) are the inverse of those of d3g, and so on.

A generalization of Dirac’s δ is found by replacing δ(x) with δ[q(x)], with q(x) a function having one or more zeros. Let x1 be a simple zero of q, namely, q ′(x1) �= 0, and consider the contribution of it to the integral

∫ +∞ −∞ δ[q(x)] dx. Observing that in

a finite neighborhood I1 of x1 there are no other zeros, one can determine such a contribution by replacingq(x) withq ′(x1) (x−x1); in this way, to bring the calculation back to the standard form one may provisionally scale the differential dx by 1/q ′(x1). However, if the scaling factor were negative, the evenness of δ would be violated; thus, the correct scaling factor is |q ′(x1)|, and

∫

I1

δ[q(x)] f (x) dx = 1|q ′(x1)| f (x1). (C.57)

If q has n simple zeros, from (C.57) it follows

∫ +∞

−∞ δ[q(x)] f (x) dx = 1|q ′(x1)|

f (x1) + . . .+ 1

|q ′(xn)| f (xn). (C.58)

C.6 Moments Expansion

For a given function f (k) consider the integral

Mn = ∫ +∞

−∞ knf (k) dk, n = 0, 1, . . . (C.59)

It is assumed that the integral converges for any n. This implies that f vanishes at infinity with a strength larger than any power. As the present considerations apply to a distribution function, the vanishing of f is typically of the exponential type. The

C.6 Moments Expansion 613

quantity Mn is called moment of order n of function f . Thanks to its properties, f can be Fourier transformed; let

g(y) = Ff = 1√ 2π

∫ +∞

−∞ f (k) exp (−i y k) dk. (C.60)

Using the Taylor expansion exp (−i y k) = ∑∞n=0 (−i y k)n/n! yields

g(y) = ∞ ∑

n=0

1

n! (−i)n Mn√

2π yn. (C.61)

The latter is the Taylor expansion of g around the origin; it follows

(−i)n Mn√ 2π

= (

dng

dyn

)

0

. (C.62)

The above analysis shows that, if the moments Mn of f (k) are known, from them one constructs the Fourier transform g(y) = Ff by means of a Taylor series. Then, one recovers the original function from the inverse transform f (k) = F−1g. In conclusion, the knowledge of the set of moments of f is equivalent to the knowledge of f . The result holds true also in the multi-dimensional case f = f (k), where

Ml+m+n = ∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ kl1 k

m 2 k

n 3 f (k) d

3k, l,m, n = 0, 1, . . . (C.63)

is the moment of order l +m+ n of f . If only the lower-order moments are used, then the Taylor series for the Fourier

transform is truncated and provides an approximation g̃ for g. As a consequence of this approximation, the inverse transform f̃ = F−1g̃ provides an approximate form of the original function f .

An extension of the above concepts is obtained by replacing the monomial ex- pression kl1 k

m 2 k

n 3 with a function α(k), that can be expressed by a polynomial

interpolation. In this case, in fact, the integral of α(k) f (k) is a combination of moments of f . A further generalization consists in considering f , α, or both, as functions of other variables besides k:

Mα(r, t) = ∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ α(r, k, t) f (r, k, t) d3k. (C.64)

If f (r, k, t) is the solution of a differential equation generated by an operator A, say, Af = 0, one can derive a set of moments from such an equation by selecting different forms of α:

∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ αAf d3k = 0. (C.65)

Each moment depends on the other variables r, t . If operator A contains the deriva- tives with respect to r, t , or both, then the moment of Af = 0 is a differential equation in r, t , or both.

( x

)

C.7 Error Function

The error function and the complementary error function are defined, respectively, as

erf (x) = 2√ π

∫ x

0 exp ( − ξ 2) dξ , erfc (x) = 1 − erf (x). (C.66)

From the definitions (C.66) and from the Gauss integral (C.23) the following properties are derived:

d

dx erf (x) = 2√

π exp ( − x2), erf (−x) = − erf (x), (C.67)

erf (−∞) = −1, erf (0) = 0, erf ( +∞) = 1, (C.68)

erfc (−∞) = 2, erfc (0) = 1, erfc ( +∞) = 0. (C.69)

Integrating by parts yields ∫ x

0 erfc (ξ ) dξ = x erfc (x) + 1√

π

[

1 − exp (−x2) ]

. (C.70)

Applying the de l’Hôpital rule shows that the first term at the right hand side of (C.70) vanishes for x → +∞. It follows

∫ +∞

0 erfc (x) dx = 1√

π . (C.71)

Still applying the de l’Hôpital rule shows that

lim x→0

erf (x)

x = 2√

π , lim

x→+∞ erfc (x)

exp (−x2) = limx→+∞ 1/ √ π

x , (C.72)

C.8 Parametrized Gaussian Function 615

whence

erf (x) ≃ 2√ π x for |x| ≪ 1, erfc (x) ≃ 1√

π

exp (−x2) x

for x ≫ 1. (C.73)

Other applications of the integration by parts yield

Y = ∫ x

C.8 Parametrized Gaussian Function

The relations introduced in Sects. C.3 and C.7 are useful for investigating the properties of function

Δ(x − ξ , a) = exp [−(x − ξ ) 2/(4 a)]√

4π a , a > 0. (C.75)

The behavior of Δ in the limit a → 0 depends on the argument x − ξ , namely

lim a→0

Δ(x − ξ , a) =

⎧

⎨

⎩

0 ξ �= x +∞ ξ = x

(C.76)

In contrast, its integral over ξ is independent of x and a. In fact, using (C.23) after letting μ = (x − ξ )/

√ 4a yields

∫ +∞

−∞ Δ(x − ξ , a) dξ = 1√

π

∫ +∞

−∞ exp ( − μ2) dμ = 1. (C.77)

Adopting the same variable change leading to (C.77) and using (C.23, C.66) yields

∫ 0

−∞ Δ(x − ξ , a) dξ = 1

2 erfc

( x√ 4a

)

. (C.78)

The relations (C.77, C.78) hold also in the limit for a → 0, provided the limit is calculated after the integration. This property is typical of the functions that generate the Dirac δ (Sect. C.4). In fact it can be shown that for a continuous function g(x) the following holds:

lim a→0

∫ +∞

−∞ g(ξ )Δ(x − ξ , a) dξ = g(x). (C.79)

616 Appendix C Special Integrals

Other examples of δ-generating functions are given in Sect. C.4. This section is concluded by showing that Δ(x− ξ , a) admits an integral representation of the form

Δ(x − ξ , a) = 1 2π

∫ +∞

−∞ exp [ik(x − ξ ) − ak2] dk. (C.80)

To prove (C.80) one recasts the argument of the exponential by means of the identity

ik(x − ξ ) − ak2 = − (x − ξ ) 2

4a − a

[

k − i(x − ξ ) 2a

]2

, (C.81)

and uses (C.23) with √ a [k−i(x−ξ )/(2a)] as the integration variable. It is interesting

to note in passing that letting ξ = 0, a = σ 2/2 in (C.80) yields

exp [−x2/(2 σ 2)] = σ√ 2π

∫ +∞

−∞ exp ( − σ 2 k2/2) exp (i k x) dk, (C.82)

namely, the Gaussian function is the Fourier transform of itself.

C.9 Euler’s Beta Function

The function defined by the integral

B(λ, μ) = ∫ 1

0 xλ−1 (1 − x)μ−1 dx, (C.83)

with λ, μ complex numbers such that ℜ(λ) > 0, ℜ(μ) > 0, is called Euler’s Beta function or Euler’s integral of the first kind [65]. Letting x = y/(y+1) and replacing y with x gives (C.83) the equivalent form

B(λ, μ) = ∫ +∞

0 xλ−1 (1 + x)−(λ+μ) dx. (C.84)

Limiting the variables’ range to 0 < ℜ(λ),ℜ(μ) < 1 and letting μ = 1 − λ, T0(λ) = B(λ, 1 − λ) (C.85)

yields

T0(λ) = ∫ +∞

0

xλ−1

1 + x dx = π

sin (λπ ) . (C.86)

The last equality is demonstrated by applying Cauchy’s residue theorem [114, Sect. 64] to the function f (z) = zλ−1/(1 + z), with z complex, that over the real axis reduces to the integrand of (C.86). The relation (C.86) can be exploited for calculating other integrals. For instance, for λ real one lets λ = 1/(2μ), x = y2μ to find

∫ +∞

0

1

1 + y2μ dy = π/(2μ)

sin [π/(2μ)] , μ >

1

2 . (C.87)

C.10 Euler’s Gamma Function 617

C.10 Euler’s Gamma Function

The function defined by the integral

Γ (λ) = ∫ +∞

0 xλ−1 exp (−x) dx, (C.88)

with λ a complex number such that ℜ(λ) > 0, is called Euler’s Gamma function or Euler’s integral of the second kind [33, Sect. 1.3].5 The negative of its derivative Γ ′ = dΓ/dλ calculated for λ = 1 is called Euler’s constant, γ = −Γ ′(1) = ∫ +∞

0 exp (−x) log (x) dx ≃ 0.5772. From (C.88) one finds Γ (1) = 1 and, after integrating by parts,

Γ (λ+ 1) = λΓ (λ). (C.89)

If λ = n = 1, 2, . . . (C.89) yields

Γ (n+ 1) = nΓ (n) = n(n− 1)Γ (n− 1) = . . . = n!. (C.90)

The definition of Γ is extended by analytic continuation to the complex plane with the exception of the points λ = 0,−1,−2, . . . ,−n, . . . . At each negative integer −n, the function Γ has a simple pole with a residue equal to (−1)n/n! [65], namely,

lim λ→−n

(λ+ n)Γ (λ) = (−1) n

n! , n = 0, 1, 2 . . . (C.91)

A straightforward calculation shows that the beta and gamma functions are connected by the relation [65]

Γ (λ)Γ (μ) = Γ (λ+ μ)B(λ, μ). (C.92)

Thanks to (C.92) one extends the definition of B to the complex plane with the exception of the points λ, μ, λ + μ = 0,−1,−2, . . . ,−n, . . . . Moreover, limiting the variables’ range to 0 < ℜ(λ),ℜ(μ) < 1 and letting μ = 1−λ so that Γ (λ+μ) = Γ (1) = 1, from (C.86) one finds

Γ (λ)Γ (1 − λ) = ∫ +∞

0

xλ−1

1 + x dx = T0(λ), 0 < ℜ(λ) < 1. (C.93)

For λ = 1/2 (C.93) yields

Γ

( 1

2

)

= √π (C.94)

5 As remarked in [33], Legendre’s notation Γ (λ) is unfortunate because the argument that appears at the right hand side of the definition is λ− 1. Gauss used the notation Π (λ− 1) for the left hand side of C.88.

618 Appendix C Special Integrals

whence, thanks to (C.89),

Γ

( 3

= 1 2 Γ

Iterating (C.95) and comparing with (C.33) shows that Γ (m + 1/2) = 2 I2m(1), m = 0, 1, 2, . . .

C.11 Gamma Function’s Asymptotic Behavior

Euler’s Gamma function introduced in Sect. C.10, considered for real values of λ, lends itself to a significant application of the asymptotic analysis. Specifically, one seeks another function f (λ), expressible through elementary functions, such that limλ→∞ [Γ (λ + 1)/f (λ)] = 1. The asymptotic analysis applied to the Γ function shows that [26]

lim λ→∞

Γ (λ+ 1) λλ+1/2 exp (−λ) =

√ 2π , (C.96)

namely, the function sought is f (λ) = √

2π λλ+1/2 exp (−λ). Equation (C.96) is called Stirling’s formula. Remembering (C.90) one has Γ (λ+ 1) = Γ (n+ 1) = n! when λ is a natural number. From (C.96) it follows

n! ≃ √

2π nn+1/2 exp (−n) = √

2π n (n/e)n , (C.97)

that provides an approximation to the factorial for n ≫ 1. Letting by way of example n = 10, the rounded value of the right hand side of (C.97) turns out to be 3 598 696, that differs from 10! = 3 628 800 by less than 1%.

The asymptotic value of the derivative of logΓ is also of interest, for instance when determining the equilibrium distribution of particles in statistical mechanics (Sects. 6.4, 15.8.1,15.8.2). Using (C.96) one finds

d

dλ logΓ (λ+ 1) ≃ 1

2 λ + log λ ≃ log λ, λ ≫ 1. (C.98)

C.12 Integrals Related to the Harmonic Oscillator

Consider the integral

I (s) = ∫ 1

0

dξ√ 1 − ξ s , (C.99)

where s is a real parameter, s > 0. Letting u = ξ s one finds 1/√1 − ξ s = (1 − u)1/2−1, dξ = u1/s−1 du/s whence, using (C.83, C.92, C.94),

I (s) = 1 s B(1/s, 1/2) =

√ π

s

Γ (1/s)

Γ (1/s + 1/2) . (C.100)

C.13 Fermi Integrals 619

By way of example I (2) = π/2, which can also be derived directly from (C.99). When s → ∞ one can use (C.91) with n = 0. It follows

lim s→∞

I (s) = 1. (C.101)

Now consider the integral

J (s) = ∫ 1

0

dξ√ 1/ξ s − 1 , (C.102)

still with s > 0. The same procedure used for calculating I (s) yields

J (s) = 1 s B(1/s + 1/2, 1/2) =

√ π

s

Γ (1/s + 1/2) Γ (1/s + 1) =

π

s

1

I (s) , (C.103)

and lims→∞ J (s) = 0. By way of example J (1) = π/2, which can also be derived directly from (C.102). The integrals (C.100, C.103) appear in the theory of the harmonic oscillator (Sect. 3.3 and Problems 3.1, 3.2).

C.13 Fermi Integrals

The Fermi integral of order α is defined as

Φα(ξ ) = 1

Γ (α + 1)

∫ ∞

0

xα

1 + exp (x − ξ ) dx, α > −1, (C.104)

where Γ is defined by (C.88) and α is a real parameter. The constraint α > −1 guarantees the convergence of the integral. If −ξ ≫ 1 one has exp (x − ξ ) ≥ exp (−ξ ) ≫ 1 and, from (C.88),

Φα(ξ ) ≃ exp (ξ )

Γ (α + 1)

∫ ∞

0 xα exp (−x) dx = exp (ξ ), ξ ≫ −1. (C.105)

A relation between Fermi integral of different order is found by considering, for some α > 0, the integral of order α − 1:

1

Γ (α)

∫ ∞

0

xα−1

1 + exp (x − ξ ) dx = 1

α Γ (α)

∫ ∞

0

xα exp (x − ξ ) [

1 + exp (x − ξ ) ]2 dx, (C.106)

where the right hand side is derived through an integration by parts. Observing that α Γ (α) = Γ (α+1) and using again (C.104) shows that the right hand side of (C.106) is equal to dΦα/dξ . Then,

dΦα dξ

= Φα−1, d logΦα

dξ = Φα−1

Φα . (C.107)

620 Appendix C Special Integrals

The Fermi integrals are positive by construction; from the first relation in (C.107) it then follows that the Fermi integrals are monotonically-increasing functions of the argument ξ . The Fermi integral of order 0 is expressed in terms of elementary functions,

Φ0 = log [

exp (ξ ) + 1 ]

. (C.108)

Approximations for the Fermi integrals are found, e.g., in [6, Appendix C]. In the applications to the semiconductor theory the Fermi integrals of small half-integer order (1/2, 3/2) are the most important ones (Sects. 18.2, 19.6.4). Remembering (C.94, C.95), they read

Φ1/2(ξ ) = ∫ ∞

0

2 x1/2/ √ π

1 + exp (x − ξ ) dx, Φ3/2(ξ ) = ∫ ∞

0

(4/3) x3/2/ √ π

1 + exp (x − ξ ) dx. (C.109)

C.14 Hölder’s Inequality

Hölder’s inequality states that for any pair of real constants b, c > 1 such that 1/b + 1/c = 1 it is

∫

η

|F G| dx ≤ (∫

η

|F |b dx )1/b (∫

η

|G|c dx )1/c

, (C.110)

where F , G are any complex functions defined over the real interval η and such that the integrals in (C.110) converge. The inequality is proven starting from the function ϕ(r) = rb − b r + b − 1, r > 0, b > 1, whose first derivative is ϕ′(r) = b rb−1 − b and the second one ϕ′′ = b (b − 1) rb−2. As a consequence, for r > 0 the function has only one minimum, located at r = 1. The inequality rb+b ≥ b r+1 then holds, whence

rb−1

b + 1

c r ≥ 1, c = b

b − 1 > 1. (C.111)

Let F1(x) and G1(x) be any two complex functions defined over η and fulfilling the normalization condition

∫

η

|F1|b dx = ∫

η

|G1|c dx = 1. (C.112)

Letting rb−1 = |F1|b−1/|G1| and replacing in (C.111) yields

|F1|b b

+ |G1| c

c − |F1 G1| ≥ 0,

1

b + 1

c = 1. (C.113)

C.15 Integrals Related to the Electromagnetic Modes 621

Since the function at the left hand side of (C.113) is non negative, its integral is non negative as well. Integrating (C.113) over η and using the normalization condition (C.112) yields

∫

η

|F1 G1| dx ≤ 1

b + 1

c = 1. (C.114)

On the other hand the normalization condition also yields

(∫

η

|F1|b dx )1/b

= (∫

η

|G1|c dx )1/c

= 1, (C.115)

whence ∫

η

|F1G1| dx ≤ (∫

η

|F1|b dx )1/b (∫

η

|G1|c dx )1/c

. (C.116)

As (C.116) is homogeneous, it still holds after replacing F1, G1 with F = λF1 and G = μG1, where λ, μ are arbitrary positive real numbers. This proves Hölder’s inequality (C.110).

C.15 Integrals Related to the Electromagnetic Modes

In several applications (e.g., calculations related to the modes of the electromagnetic field, Sect. 5.5) one must evaluate integrals of the form

Y = ∫

V

exp [i (k ± k′) · r] d3r , (C.117)

where k = k(n1, n2, n3) is given by

k = n1 2π

d1 i1 + n2

2π

d2 i2 + n3

2π

d3 i3, ni = 0,±1,±2, . . . , (C.118)

i1, i2, i3 being the unit vectors parallel to the coordinate axes. The integration domain in (C.117) is a box whose sides d1, d2, d3 are aligned with the axes and start from the origin (Fig. 5.1). The volume of the box is V = d1 d2 d3. As (k ± k′) · r = (k1±k′1) x1+ (k2 ±k′2) x2 + (k3±k′3) x3, where the upper (lower) signs hold together, the integral becomes Y = Y1 Y2 Y3, with

Yi = ∫ di

0 exp [i (ki ± k′i) xi] dxi =

exp [i (ki ± k′i) di] − 1 i (ki ± k′i)

. (C.119)

Letting θi = (ki ± k′i) di/2 = π (ni ± n′i), (C.119) becomes

Yi = di exp (i θi) exp (i θi) − exp ( − i θi)

2 i θi = di exp (i θi)

sin θi θi

. (C.120)

622 Appendix C Special Integrals

It follows that Yi = 0 if ni ± n′i �= 0, while Yi = di if ni ± n′i = 0. Combining the three integrals shows that it is Y = 0 if k ± k′ �= 0, while it is Y = V if k ± k′ = 0. The result is recast in a compact form by means of the three-dimensional extension of the Kronecker symbol (A.18):

Y = V δ[k ± k′, 0] = V δ[k ± k′], (C.121)

where the last form is obtained by dropping the zero for the sake of conciseness. Compare (C.117, C.121) with (C.56) and the comments therein.

C.16 Riemann’s Zeta Function

The function defined by

ζ (λ, a) = ∞ ∑

k=1

1

(k + a)λ , (C.122)

where λ is a complex number with ℜ(λ) > 1 and a ≥ 0 is real, is called Riemann’s Zeta function. It can be represented in integral form by combining it with the Gamma function (C.88): letting x = (k + a) y in the latter, then replacing y back with x, yields

Γ (λ) = (k + a)λ ∫ +∞

0 xλ−1 exp [−(k + a) x] dx. (C.123)

Dividing (C.123) by (k + a)λ, letting k = 1, 2, . . . , and adding over k provides

Γ (λ) ∞ ∑

k=1

1

(k + a)λ = ∫ +∞

0 xλ−1 exp (−ax)

[ ∞ ∑

k=1 exp ( − kx)

]

dx, (C.124)

where ∑∞

k=1 exp ( − k x) = exp (−x) [1 + exp (−x) + exp (−2 x) + . . . ] = 1/[ exp (x) − 1], so that from (C.122),

ζ (λ, a) = 1 Γ (λ)

∫ +∞

0

xλ−1

exp (x) − 1 exp (−a x) dx, ℜ(λ) > 1. (C.125)

Remembering (C.89) one finds that (C.125) fulfills the recursive relation

∂

∂a ζ (λ, a) = −λ ζ (λ+ 1, a). (C.126)

Also, letting a = 0 and λ = 2m, with m = 1, 2, . . . transforms (C.125) into ∫ +∞

0

x2m−1

exp (x) − 1 dx = Γ (2m) ζ (2m, 0) = (2π )2m

4m |B2m|, (C.127)

C.16 Riemann’s Zeta Function 623

with B2m = (−1)m+1 |B2m|, m ≥ 1 the Bernoulli number6 of order 2m [44]. Thanks to (C.127) one calculates integrals used in different applications. For instance, letting m = 2 and using B4 = −1/30

∫ +∞

0

x3

exp (x) − 1 dx = 1

15 π4, (C.128)

that is used in (15.78) to calculate the Lagrangian multiplier in the equilibrium statistics for photons. From (C.125) one derives another important class of integrals; in fact, replacing x with 2 x in the denominator of (C.125) yields

∫ +∞

0

xλ−1

exp (2 x) − 1 exp (−a x) dx = 2 −λ Γ (λ) ζ (λ, a/2), ℜ(λ) > 1 (C.129)

whence, using the identity 2/[ exp (2 x) − 1] = 1/[ exp (x) − 1] − 1/[ exp (x) + 1] within (C.125), (C.129) provides

∫ +∞

0

xλ−1

exp (x) + 1 exp (−a x) dx = Γ (λ) [

ζ (λ, a) − 21−λ ζ (λ, a/2) ]

. (C.130)

Letting a = 0 and λ = 2m, m = 1, 2, . . . in the latter, and using (C.127), transforms (C.130) into

∫ +∞

0

x2m−1

exp (x) + 1 dx = π2m

2m

(

22m−1 − 1 )

|B2m|. (C.131)

For instance, for m = 1 and m = 2, (C.131) provides ∫ +∞

0

x

exp (x) + 1 dx = 1

12 π2,

∫ +∞

0

x3

exp (x) + 1 dx = 7

120 π4. (C.132)

6 The Bernoulli numbers are defined by the series expansion x/[ exp (x) − 1] = ∑∞0 Bn xn/n!, with |x| < 2π . It is B0 = 1, B1 = −1/2, B2 = 1/6, B4 = −1/30. Apart from B1, all Bernoulli numbers of odd index vanish.

Solutions

Problems of Chap. 1

1.1 The distance between A and B is a functional of y:

G[y] = ∫

AB

√

dx2 + dy2 = ∫ b

a

√

1 + ẏ2 dx.

As g(y, ẏ, x) = √

1 + ẏ2 it is ∂g/∂y = 0, whence the Euler–Lagrange equation reads

0 = d dx

∂g

∂ẏ = d

dx

2ẏ

2 g = ÿg − ẏ(2ẏÿ/2 g)

g2 = ÿ

g3 (g2 − ẏ2) = ÿ

g3 ,

that is, ÿ = 0, y = c1x + c2. The two constants are found from c1a + c2 = ya , c1b + c2 = yb. 1.2 Letting H = E one finds

x2

a2 + p

2

b2 = 1, a =

√

2E/c, b = √

2mE.

The curves are ellipses whose axes are proportional to √ E. The area of each ellipse is

π a b = 2πE/ω, withω = √c/m. As shown in Sect. 3.3, ω is the angular frequency of the oscillator, so that the area becomes E T , with T = 2π/ω the period. As time evolves, the phase point follows the curve in the clockwise direction; in fact, as the phase point reaches the maximum elongation xM > 0 from the left, the momentum at xM changes from positive to negative.

1.3 Letting H = E one finds for the maximum elongation xM = (s E/c)1/s . Note that the units of c depend on the value of s. The form of the constant-energy curves becomes more and more rectangular as s increases. As in the previous exercise, the phase point follows the curve in the clockwise direction.

© Springer Science+Business Media New York 2015 627 M. Rudan, Physics of Semiconductor Devices, DOI 10.1007/978-1-4939-1151-6

J (E) = √mc ∮

The first of (2.51) then yields ν = ẇ = ∂H/∂J = ∂E/∂J = ω/(2π ).

Problems of Chap. 3

3.1 Like in problem 1.3, letting H = E > 0 one finds for the maximum elongation xM = (s E/c)1/s , where the units of c depend on the value of s. The motion is limited to the interval [−xM ,+xM ] and the potential energy is symmetric with respect to the origin. Using (2.47) and exploiting the symmetry yields

T = 4 √

m

2

∫ xM

0

dx√ E − V (x) =

√

8m

E

∫ xM

1 − (x/xM )s ]−1/2

dx.

Letting ξ = x/xM and using (C.99, C.100) yields

T = √

8m

E xM

∫ 1

0

dξ√ 1 − ξ s =

√ 8π m

(1/s)Γ (1/s)

Γ (1/s + 1/2) ( s

c

)1/s E1/s−1/2.

The result shows that the case s = 2, namely, that of the linear harmonic oscillator, is special. In fact, the period does not depend on the total energy, whereas for s �= 2 it does. Still in the case s = 2 one finds T = 2π/ω, ω = √c/m, as should be (compare with the results of Sect. 3.3). In turn, the case s → ∞ yields s1/s → 1, c1/s → 1 whence, using (C.101), lims→∞ T =

√ 8m/E. The above is the period

in a square well of length 2 (compare with the description of Sect. 3.2). In fact, as s → ∞, the potential energy c|x|s/s transforms into a square well with xM = 1. The potential energy is shown in Fig. D.1 for some values of s. Thanks to the result of this problem one may tune the form of the potential energy to make the period proportional to a chosen power h = 1/s − 1/2 ≥ −1/2 of the energy. For instance, letting s = 2/3 makes T proportional to E, namely, T =

√

m/(3c3) 2πE.

3.2 The solution is similar to that of Problem 3.1. Letting H = E < 0 one finds for the maximum elongation xM = [k/(s |E|)]1/s , where the units of k depend on the value of s. The motion is limited to the interval [−xM ,+xM ] and the potential energy is symmetric with respect to the origin. Using (2.47) and exploiting the symmetry yields

The Coulomb case s = 1 yields T = √

Note that in the case considered here the particle crosses the origin because the initial conditions are such that its trajectory is aligned with the x axis. The limit s → ∞ yields s1/s → 1, c1/s → 1 whence, using (C.101, C.103), lims→∞ T = 0. From (3.36) one extracts μ/s0 = tan [(π − χ )/4], to find

2μ/s0 1 − (μ/s0)2

= 2μ s0 s20 − μ2

= tan ( π − χ

2

)

= 1 tan (χ/2)

,

where s0 is given by the second of (3.33). It follows that s20 − μ2 = 2 λ s0 and tan (χ/2) = λ/μ. Then, noting that (3.23) contains sin2 (χ/2) = tan2 (χ/2)/[1 + tan2 (χ/2)], and using (3.73), one finds sin2 (χ/2) = 1/(1+ c2/λ2). The expression of λ is taken from the first of (3.32), with α given by (3.75). Inserting the result into (3.23) yields

T1b = α2 (1 −m1/m2)2 + c2 T 21a α2 (1 +m1/m2)2 + c2 T 21a

ϕ = ϕ(a) + ϕ′(c) (x − a) − x ∫ x

4.2 Letting c = a in the solution to Problem 4.1 yields at any point x within [a, b] the expression

ϕ(x) = ϕ(a) + ϕ′(a) (x − a) − x ∫ x

a

̺(ξ )

ε0 dξ +

∫ x

a

ξ ̺(ξ )

ε0 dξ.

For x > b it is ̺ = 0 so that the solution of ϕ′′ = 0 is linear and has the form ϕ(x) = ϕ(b)+ ϕ′(b) (x − b). The term ϕ(b) in the latter is obtained by letting x = b in the above expression of ϕ(x). One finds ϕ(b) = ϕ(a)+ϕ′(a) (b−a)−bM0 +M1, with

M0 = ∫ b

a

̺(ξ )

ε0 dξ , M1 =

∫ b

a

ξ ̺(ξ )

ε0 dξ

the first two moments of ̺/ε0 (compare with Sect. C.6). The derivative ϕ′ is found from Problem 4.1 with c = a, and reads

ϕ′(x) = ϕ′(a) − ∫ x

a

̺(ξ )

ε0 dξ ,

whence ϕ′(b) = ϕ′(a) −M0. Using the expressions of ϕ(b), ϕ′(b) thus found yields

ϕ(x) = ϕ(a) + ϕ′(a) (x − a) −M0 x +M1, x > b.

4.3 From the findings of Problem 4.2 one observes that the solution ϕ is invariant for any charge density ˜̺ that leaves M0 and M1 unchanged. Due to this, if both M0, M1 differ from zero, the new charge density must contain two adjustable parameters in order to fit the values of M0, M1 through the expressions introduced in Problem 4.2. If only one moment differs from zero, one parameter suffices, while no parameter is necessary if both moments are equal to zero. Figure D.4 gives an example of charge density such that M0 = 0 and M1 = 0. 4.4 The starting point is the solution for x > b found in Problem 4.2. When the charge density is removed, the new solution reads

ϕ(x) = ϕ̃(a) + ϕ̃′(a) (x − a).

For x > b the two solutions become equal to each other by letting ϕ̃(a) = ϕ(a) − M0 a +M1 and ϕ̃′(a) = ϕ′(a) −M0.

632 Solutions

Fig. D.4 Example of charge density such that M0 = 0 and M1 = 0

ρ 0

− ρ 0

− ξ 0

ξ 0

ξ

ρ

4.5 Considering that the value of h is unknown, the integrals that define the moments (Problem 4.2) must be extended from −∞ to +∞. One finds μ = M0, h = M1/M0. If h ≥ a, the solution is given by ϕ = ϕ(a) + ϕ′(a) (x − a) − M0 x + M1 for x ≥ h, while it is given by ϕ = ϕ(a) + ϕ′(a) (x − a) for x < h. If h < a, the solution is given by ϕ = ϕ(a) + ϕ′(a) (x − a) for x ≥ h, while it is given by ϕ = ϕ(a) + ϕ′(a) (x − a) − M0 x + M1 for x < h. At h the electric potential is continuous, ϕ(h+) = ϕ(h−) = ϕ(a) + ϕ′(a) (h − a), whereas the electric field is discontinuous, ϕ′(h−) − ϕ′(h+) = M0. The case M0 �= 0, M1 = 0 yields μ = M0, h = 0, while the case M0 = 0, M1 �= 0 can not be fulfilled by μδ(x − h).

Problems of Chap. 5

5.1 From n = n(x1) one finds that gradn = i1 dn/dx1 is parallel to x1 whereas dn/dx2 = dn/dx3 = 0. From the eikonal Eq. (5.57) it follows

d

ds

(

n dx2 ds

)

= 0, d ds

(

n dx3 ds

)

= 0,

whence n dx2/ds = const, n dx3/ds = const. The ratio of the latter relations yields dx2/dx3 = const, namely, x2 = ax3 + b, where a, b are constants. This expression is one of the two parametric equations u(x1, x2, x3) = 0, v(x1, x2, x3) = 0 describing the ray, and shows that the ray belongs to a plane parallel to x1. By a suitable rotation around x1, such that x2 → x ′2, x3 → x ′3, the plane of the ray is made parallel to the plane x1 x ′2, so that the third coordinate x

′ 3 is fixed. In the new reference,

let ϑ be the angle between the direction of the ray and x1 at some point P ; it is dx1 = cosϑ ds, dx ′2 = sin ϑ ds. The eikonal equation in the new reference then provides

n dx ′2 ds

= const, n sin ϑ = const.

Solutions 633

5.2 Like in Problem 5.1 one considers the case where the refraction index depends only on the x1 coordinate. Let the medium be made of three regions separated by two planes parallel to each other.

The two external regions A and B have a constant refraction index, nA and, respectively, nB �= nA. The internal region I, whose thickness is s, has a refraction index that varies continuously from nA to nB as x1 varies from the A-I interface to the I-B interface. Applying the solution of Problem 5.1 to this case shows that nA sin ϑA = const everywhere in region A, hence the ray is a straight line there; similarly it is nB sin ϑB = const everywhere in region B, with the same constant. It follows

nB sin ϑB = nA sin ϑA.

Unless ϑA = 0, the position of the ray along the x ′2 axis at the I-B interface is different from that at the A-I interface; if, however, s is made to vanish, the position becomes the same, this yielding the Descartes law of refraction: the ray crossing an interface between two media is continuous, whereas its slopes on the two sides of the interface fulfill (D). The result still holds in the cases where the interface between the two media is not planar, provided its curvature is small enough to make geometrical optics applicable.

Problems of Chap. 6

6.1 Letting ϑ = β h ν, with β = 1/(kB T ), the Boltzmann distribution takes the form Nn = N0 exp (−nϑ), whence

∞ ∑

n=0 Nn = N0

[

1 + exp (−ϑ) + exp (−2ϑ) + . . . ]

= N0 1 − exp (−ϑ) ,

and

∞ ∑

n=0 n h ν Nn = h ν N0

[

exp (−ϑ) + 2 exp (−2ϑ) + 3 exp (−3ϑ) + . . . ]

.

Observing that n exp (−nϑ) = −d exp (−nϑ)/dϑ , one finds ∞ ∑

n=0 n h ν Nn = −h ν

d

dϑ

( ∞ ∑

n=0 Nn −N0

)

= h ν N0 exp (−ϑ)[ 1 − exp (−ϑ)

]2 ,

whence

En = ∑∞

n=0 n h ν Nn ∑∞

n=0 Nn = h ν

exp (ϑ) − 1 = h ν

exp (β h ν) − 1 .

Problems of Chap. 8

8.1 Consider the homogeneous equation associated to (8.76), g′′ + a g′ + b g = 0, and let f = g h and u = h′; this splits (8.76) into the system

g′′ + a g′ + b g = 0, g u′ + (2 g′ + a g) u = c.

If g is known, then u is found by integrating a first-order equation, whence f = g ∫

u dξ . To find g one lets A(x) = ∫

a dξ , g = exp (−A/2) w, this transforming the homogeneous equation for g into

w′′ + q w = 0, q = b − a2/4 − a′/2,

which is a time-independent Schrödinger equation.

Problems of Chap. 10

10.1 To determine the time evolution of the expectation value of the wavepacket for a free particle one starts from the general expression (9.5), with wk(r) andEk = h̄ ωk given by (9.22), and ck given by the second relation in (9.6). The wave function is assumed normalized,

∫ +∞ −∞ |ψ(r, t)|2 d3r =

∫ +∞ −∞ |c(k)|2 d3k = 1. Using the first

spatial coordinate x1 and defining mk = ck exp (−iωk t), the following are of use: x1 wk = −i ∂wk/∂k1, x21 wk = −∂2wk/∂k21 , and

− ∫ +∞

∫ +∞

∂k21 dk1,

i ∂mk

(

The expectation value 〈x1〉 = 〈ψ |x1|ψ〉 involves an integration over r to calculate the scalar product, an integration over k to calculate the integral expression of ψ , and an integration over k′ to calculate the integral expression of ψ∗. Performing the integration over r first, letting c′k = c(k′), ω′k = ω(k′), and using (C.56) yields

∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ u |ck|2 d3k = const.

If |ck|2 is even with respect to all components of k, the expectation value of r does not change with respect to the initial value r0. Otherwise, it moves at constant speed.

where the definition of the squared length of a complex vector is found in (A.2) and (A.4). The standard deviation of the wave packet in the r space is the positive square root of 〈r · r〉 − 〈r〉 · 〈r〉 = ∑3i=1 (�xi)2, where the expression of 〈r〉 was derived in Prob. 10.1. It is easily shown that the standard deviation diverges with t . In fact, the leading term of 〈x21 〉 and, respectively, 〈x1〉2 is

〈x21 〉 ∼ t2 ∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ u21 |ck|2 d3k, 〈x1〉2 ∼ t2

(∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ u1 |ck|2 d3k

)2

,
