∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ u21|ck|2 d3k >

(∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ u1|ck|2 d3k

)2

,

where the strict inequality holds because f and g are not proportional to each other. For the leading term it follows that (�x1)2 = 〈x21 〉 − 〈x1〉2 ∼ const × t2, where the constant is strictly positive. The same reasoning applies to x2, x3. In conclusion, the standard deviation �xi associated with the ith coordinate diverges in time with the first power of t .

Solutions 637

10.3 Still with reference to the wave packet of a free particle used in Problems 10.1 and 10.2, the time evolution of the expectation value in the p space is found starting with the first component p1 of momentum. The corresponding operator is p̂1 = −i h̄ ∂/∂x1, and the following relations are of use: p̂1wk = h̄ k1 wk, p̂21wk = h̄2 k21 wk. The expectation value 〈p1〉 = 〈ψ |p1|ψ〉 involves an integration over r to calculate the scalar product, an integration over k to calculate the integral expression of ψ , and an integration over k′ to calculate the integral expression of ψ∗. Performing the integration over r first, letting c′k = c(k′), ω′k = ω(k′), and using (C.56) yields

〈p1〉 = ∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ h̄ k1 |ck|2 d3k = p01.

The real constant p01 defined above is independent of time. In conclusion, repeating the calculation for p2 and p3, and letting p0 = (p01,p02,p03), the following holds: 〈p〉 = p0. If |ck|2 is even with respect to all components of k, the expectation value of p is zero.

10.4 The calculation of 〈ψ |p̂21|ψ〉 is carried out following the same line as in Problem 10.3, leading to

〈p21〉 = ∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ h̄2 k21 |ck|2 d3k.

Repeating the calculation for x2 and x3 yields

〈p · p〉 = ∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ h̄ k · h̄ k |ck|2 d3k.

In turn, the standard deviation of the wave packet in the p space is the positive square root of 〈p ·p〉−〈p〉 · 〈p〉 = ∑3i=1 (�pi)2. Letting f = ck, g = h̄k1ck in the Schwartz inequality (8.15) and using the normalization condition of ck yields

∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ h̄2 k21 |ck|2 d3k >

(∫∫∫ +∞

−∞ h̄ k1 |ck|2 d3k

)2

,

where the strict inequality holds because f and g are not proportional to each other. It follows that (�p1)2 = 〈p21〉−〈p1〉2 is strictly positive and constant in time. The same reasoning applies top2, p3. In conclusion, the standard deviation�pi associated with the ith component of momentum is constant in time.

10.5 One finds 〈x〉 = x0, dh̄ β/dx = h̄ k0, 〈pe〉 = h̄ k0, ⟨ p2e

2m

⟩

= h̄ 2 k20

2m , 〈Q〉 = h̄

2

8mσ 2 , 〈T 〉 = h̄

2

2m

(

k20 + 1

4 σ 2

)

.

One notes that for a fixed 〈T 〉 all non-negative values of the “convective” and “ther- mal” parts that add up to 〈T 〉 are allowed. In the particular case of a free particle, where 〈T 〉 = 〈E〉, the above shows that different values of the average momentum and “dispersion” may combine to yield the same total energy.

638 Solutions

Problems of Chap. 11

11.1 Letting b− = π a √

2m ( √ E − √E − V0)/h̄, b+ = π a

√ 2m (

√ E +√

E − V0)/h̄ and remembering that sinh b ≃ b when |b| ≪ 1 yields, with m fixed,

R(a → 0) = ( b−

b+

)2

= ( √ E −√E − V0)2

( √ E +√E − V0)2

,

that coincides with the first relation in (11.11). Conversely, when a > 0 is fixed and m is let grow one finds

R ≃ exp [2 (b− − b+)] = exp (

−4π a √

2m √

E − V0/h̄ )

,

namely, limm→∞ R = 0, this recovering the classical limit. 11.2 The maximum of the cotangent’s argument s

√

2m (E − V0)/h̄2 is found by letting E = 0. Thus,

γ = s h̄

√

−2mV0 ≃ 13.4, 13.4

π ≃ 4.3.

As a consequence, the cotangent has four complete branches and one incomplete branch in the interval V0 < E < 0, corresponding to five eigenvalues E1, . . . ,E5. Using the normalized parameter 0 < η = √1 − E/V0 < 1, the equation to be solved reads

η2 − 1/2 η √

1 − η2 = cot (γ η) .

Over the η axis, the 5 branches belong to the intervals (0,π/γ ), (π/γ , 2π/γ ), (2π/γ , 3π/γ ), (3π/γ , 4π/γ ), (4π/γ , 1).

Problems of Chap. 13

13.1 Letting Z = 1 one finds that the lowest total energy of the electron in the hydrogen atom has the value

E1(Z = 1) = − m0

2 h̄2

( q2

4π ε0

)2

.

As noted in Sect. 13.5.2, the electron is bound as long as E < 0. As a consequence, the minimum energy for which it becomes free is limn→∞ En = 0. The hydrogen atom’s ionization energy is thus found to be

Eion = 0 − E1(Z = 1) = |E1(Z = 1)| = m0

2 h̄2

( q2

4π ε0

)2

.

Replacing the constants’values of Table D.1 yieldsEion ≃ 2.18×10−18 J ≃ 13.6 eV.

Solutions 639

13.2 The time-dependent wave function is in this case ψ = w(Emin) exp (−iEmin t/h̄), whence |ψ |2 = exp (−2 r/a)/(π a3). Taking the Jacobian determinant J = r2 sin ϑ from (B.3) and using the definitions of Sect. 10.5 one finds

〈r〉 = ∫ ∞

∫ π

∫ 2π

0 r

exp (−2 r/a) π a3

r2 sin ϑ dr dϑ dϕ = 3 2 a.

From (13.89) one finds a1 = a(Z = 1) = 4π h̄2 ε0/(m0 q2) ≃ 5.3×10−11 m ≃ 0.53 Å, where the constants’ values are taken from Table D.1. Note that a1 = r1/2, with r1 is the radius of the ground state derived from the Bohr hypothesis (Sect. 7.4.4). The expectation value of r turns out to be 〈r〉 ≃ 0.8 Å.

Problems of Chap. 14

14.1 From h(0)bg = [A/(2π )3]/(q2c + q2) and q = |b − g| one finds

H (0) b (Eg) =

A2

(2π )6

∫ π

0

∫ 2π

0

1

(q2c + q2)2 sin ϑ dϑ dϕ,

A = κ Z e2/ε0. Observing that b is a fixed vector one can use it as the reference for angle ϑ , so that q2 = (b − g) · (b − g) = b2 + g2 − 2 b g cosϑ . From g = b it follows q2 = 4 g2 sin2 (ϑ/2). On the other hand it is sin ϑ dϑ = d sin2 (ϑ/2) whence, integrating over ϕ and letting μ = sin2 (ϑ/2),

H (0) b (Eg) =

A2

q2c (q2c + 4 g2) .

The dependence on Eg is found through the relation Eg = h̄2 g2/(2m).

Problems of Chap. 15

15.1 After selecting a number 0 < η < 1/2, define E+ and E− such that P (E+) = η, P (E−) = 1 − η. It follows

E+ − E− = 2 kB T log 1 − η η

.

Letting, e.g., η = 0.1 one finds E(P = 0.9) − E(P = 0.1) = 2 kB T log 9 ≃ 4.39 kB T . Similarly, letting η = 0.01 one finds E(P = 0.99) − E(P = 0.01) = 2 kB T log 99 ≃ 9.19 kB T . At T = 300 K it is kB T ≃ 25.8 meV. From the above results one finds E(P = 0.9)−E(P = 0.1) ≃ 113 meV and E(P = 0.99)−E(P = 0.01) ≃ 237 meV, respectively.

Problems of Chap. 21

21.1 Using kB T/q ≃ 26 mV (compare with (19.162)) and ni ≃ 1010 cm−3 (Table 18.2), one finds

ψ0 = kB T

q log

( NA ND

n2i

)

≃ 0.65 V. (D.1)

21.2 The relations to be used are (21.51), (21.55), and (21.57). If kp = 0, kn > 0, one finds Yp = 0, Yn = 1 − exp [−m(b)]. On the other hand it is in this case m(b) =

∫ b

a kn dx > 0, whence Yn < 1. If, instead, kn = 0, kp > 0, one finds

Yn = 0, Yp = 1 − exp [m(b)] with m(b) = − ∫ b

a kp dx < 0, whence Yp < 1. In

conclusion, the condition for avalanche never occurs.

22.1 The differential capacitance of the MOS structure, extracted from (22.19) and (22.20), reads

Csc = ± εsc√ 2LA

A

Problems of Chap. 23

23.1 The maximum initial profile is N (x = 0, t = 0) = 2Q/√πc1. Remembering (23.26), at the end of the diffusion process the profile has become N (x, t = tP ) = 2Q [π (c1+c2)]−1/2× exp

[

−x2/(c1 + c2) ]

, whenceN (x = 0, t = tP ) = 2Q [π (c1+ c2)]−1/2, with tP the process duration and c2 = 4D tP . From N (x = 0, t = tP ) = (2/3)N (x = 0, t = 0) it follows 1/√c1 + c2 = 2/(3

√ c1), c2 = (5/4) c1 and,

finally, tP = (5/16) (c1/D) = 5,000 s. 23.2 The initial and final profiles areNi(x) = 2Q exp (−x2/c1)/(πc1)1/2 and, from (23.26), Nf (x) = 2Q exp [−x2/(c1 + c2)]/[π (c1 + c2)]1/2. Letting Nf = Ni and defining r = [(c1 + c2)/c1]1/2 and a2 = (c1 + c2) c1/c2 yields r = exp (x2/a2), whence x̄ = 104 × a ( log r)1/2 ≃ 2.68 µm 23.3 Converting to seconds one finds tP = 14,400 s, whence c2 = 4D tP = 14.4 × 10−6 cm2. Considering that N (x, t = 0) = 2Q exp (−x2/c1)/(πc1)1/2 and, from (23.26), N (x, t = tP ) = 2Q exp [−x2/(c1 + c2)]/[π (c1 + c2)]1/2, the ratio sought is N (x = 0, t = tP )/N (x = 0, t = 0) = [c1/(c1 + c2)]1/2 = 0.385. 23.4 Due to (23.26), the final profile is Nf = 2Q exp [−x2/(c1 + c2)]/[π (c1 + c2)]1/2. From N (x̄) = Nf (0) one has exp (−x̄ 2/c1) = [c1/(c1 + c2)]1/2. As a consequence, the position sought is x̄ = [(c1/2) log (1 + c2/c1)]1/2 = 0.83 µm. 23.5 Due to (23.26) the final profile is Nf = 2Q exp [−x2/(c1 + c2)]/[π (c1 + c2)]1/2. Let α = 1.1. From the condition Nf (0) = N (x = α

√ c1) one derives

1/[π (c1+c2)]1/2 = exp (−α2)/(πc1)1/2, whence c1 = c2/[ exp (2α2)−1] = 0.976× 10−9 cm2.

23.6 Letting c2 = 4D t = 2.4 × 10−8 cm2 and r = c2/(c1 + c2) = 4/7, one eliminates Q at x = x0 to find N1/N2 =

√ 1 + r exp [−r x20/(c1 + 2 c2)], whence

x0 = 104 × [(1/r) (c1 + 2 c2) log ( √

1 + r N2/N1)]1/2 = 4.06 µm. 23.7 Remembering (C.71) one has Q =

∫∞ 0 NS erfc(x/

√ c) dx = NS

√ c/π ,

whence c = 4D t = λ2, t = λ2/(4D) = 2.99 × 1016 nm2 s−1 ≃ 5 min.

Fig. D.5 Normalized profiles hN/Q resulting from the drive-in diffusion of Problem 23.8. The coordinate is μ = x/h. Each profile corresponds to the value of b(t) shown in the legend. The parameter is defined by b = 4 a/h2, while a = a(t) is defined by the second of (23.10). As explained in Sect. 23.5.2, only the profile’s portion on the right of the origin must be considered

23.8 As indicated in Sect. 23.5.2, the initial profile must preliminarily be mirrored onto the negative axis with N0 = 2Q (h + x)/h2 for −h ≤ x ≤ 0 and with N0 = 0 for x < −h. Then, the profile is obtained from (23.13) as the portion of N (x) = (2Q/h2) (I− + I+) calculated for x ≥ 0, where

I− = ∫ 0

−h (h+ ξ )Δ(x − ξ , t) dξ , I+ =

∫ +h

0 (h− ξ )Δ(x − ξ , t) dξ

and Δ(x − ξ , t) is given by (C.75). Letting η = (ξ − x)/(4 a)1/2, μ = x/h, b = 4 a/h2, and using (C.66) yields

N = (Q/h) [

(μ+ 1)Y− + (μ− 1)Y+ − (b/π )1/2 (Z− + Z+) ]

,

with Y∓ = erfc(μ/ √ b)− erfc[(μ± 1)/

√ b ] and Z∓ = exp (−μ2/b)− exp [−(μ±

1)2/b]. When t → 0+ it is b → 0. This makes the Z∓ terms to vanish, while the terms containing Y∓ render the initial condition N0. When t > 0 the dose is found by integrating hN over μ from 0 to +∞. A somewhat lengthy calculation based on the expressions of Appendix C.7 shows that the integral of (b/π )1/2 (Z− + Z+) vanishes whereas that of (μ+1)Y−+(μ−1)Y+ yields unity. As expected, the result of the dose calculation is Q. The normalized profile hN/Q is shown in Fig. D.5 as a function of the normalized coordinate μ at different values of the parameter b = b(t).

Problems of Chap. 24

24.1 The relation between time t and oxide thickness s is given by (24.11), s2/cp + s/cl = t ′ with t ′ = t + s2i /cp + si/cl . Solving for s and discarding the negative solution yields s = [(c2p/c2l +4cpt ′)1/2 −cp/cl]/2, with cp/cl = 0.05 µm. It follows t ′ = t+ s2i /cp + si/cl ≃ 136/60+0.995+0.237 = 3.50 h and 4cpt ′ = 0.620 µm2.

Solutions 643

The total oxide thickness and the thickness of silicon that is consumed in the second process are, respectively, s = [(0.052 + 4cpt ′)1/2 − 0.05]/2 ≃ 0.369 µm and h = 0.44 (s − si) ≃ 70 nm. 24.2 The gradient sought is found by remembering that, from (24.10), it is cp = 2 w k0 NG DO and cl = w k0 NG vr , whence cl/cp = vr/(2DO) = 20 µm−1, vr/DO = 4 × 105 cm−1. On the other hand, from (24.7,24.6), −DO gradN = −DO dN/dx = vrNI whence dN/dx = −NO vr/DO = −4 × 1017 cm−4. 24.3 Converting the units one finds cp = 738 nm2 min−1, cl = 14.8 nm min−1. Letting h be the thickness of silicon consumed one has h = 0.44 (s − si), s = si + h/0.44 whence, from (24.11), t = (s2 − s2i )/cp + (s − si)/cl = 150 min. 24.4 Converting the units yields cp = 2000 nm2 min−1, cl = 50 nm min−1. From (24.10) it follows vr/DO = 2cl/cp = 0.05, 1 + s vr/DO = 2 whence, using (24.8), NI = NO/(1 + s vr/DO) = 15 × 1011 cm−3. 24.5 Converting the units yields cp = 11.4 nm2 s−1, cl = 0.237 nm s−1. From (24.10) the duration of the first process is found as t1 = (s2f − s2i )/cp + (sf − si)/cl . Similarly, that of the second process is t2 = (s2 − s2f )/cp + (s − sf )/cl . As the coefficients cp, cl are the same one adds the expressions of t1 and t2 to each other and lets s = si +Δs1 +Δs2. This yields t1 + t2 = (s2 − s2i )/cp + (s − si)/cl = 202 s.

24.6 Converting the units yields cl = 16.67 nm min−1. Using the definitions (24.10) of cp and cl one finds r = DO/vr = cp/(2 cl), whence tP = [(s2 − s2i )/(2r) + s − si]/cl = 13.9 min. 24.7 Letting t = tP and multiplying the first of (24.10) by cp yields s2 +bs+ c = 0 with b = cp/cl , c = −s2i − (cp/cl) si − cpt . Here si and cptP are given while cp/cl = 2DO/vr = 2.25 × 10−6 cm. Solving for s and discarding the negative root provides the final thickness s = [(b2 − 4c)1/2 − b]/2 = 76.1 nm. 24.8 From the relation ΔP = s πr2 pSi, where ΔP , s are the weight and thickness of the epitaxial layer, and r the wafer’s radius, one finds 2 r = 2√ΔP/(πspSi) ≃ 20.4 cm ≃ 8 in. 24.9 The surface concentration NS of SiCl4 is found from the relations s/t = cl = wF2 = w vr NS , whence NS = s/(w vr t) = 1 × 1016 cm−3. 24.10 Using 1/w = 5× 1022 cm−3 in the relations (24.22,24.23) yields t = s/cl = s/(wFI ) = 2 min. 24.11 Letting tP be the duration of the process one has, from (24.22,24.23), cl = s/tP = w vr NI , whence, using 1 µm = 10−4 cm, vr = s/(wNI tP ) = 200 cm min−1.

24.12 From (24.21) and the second of (24.23) one finds b = (vr +vG)/(vG wNG) = (NG/NS) (wNG)−1 = a/(wNG), whence NG = a/(w b) = 2 × (5 × 1022/4.87 × 105) = 2.05 × 1017 cm−3.
